content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												What I love about scribblenauts is its creative problem solving and peaceful attitude.Problem: Did the children of the neighborhood land their ball on the old geezer's lawn that won't give it back? Solution: Spawn a gun and kill him! It works!Problem: Nurse being chased by an angry heart?Solution: Spawn a gun and kill it!Problem: Want to contact a manager at the other side of a wall?Solution: Spawn a grenade launcher!Problem: Frozen people encased in ice?Solution: Spawn a flamethrower! Bonus: Watch their life points diminish as you melt/burn away!The thing that bugged me the most and made me sad is the cruelty towards animals. For example, as I visited a restaurant I made friends with a brown recluse spider and a cockroach, petting them and watching their happy little faces light up. Then some evil quest-giving person wanted me to kill them for a pest-control inspection, the nerve! And for a starlite fragment I had to kill my newly made bug friends?! What cruel madness is this!Also while going through the object shards achievements I had to prod a cow?! Shame on you scribblenauts. I hope they will fix those issues in future installments. In the meanwhile I will continue riding my black&red huge supersonic fire-breathing dragon that is immune to damage, while going around helping people and making their lives better (sometimes with the use of supreme firepower).

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												A charming game that expresses the innocent sense of curiosity and imagination of a young child in a way I have rarely seen.If you're not familiar with the Scribblenauts series, they are platformer sandbox puzzle games where you can summon just about any object from the dictionary (with some reasonable exceptions such as copyrighted things, alcohol, and proper nouns) and expect them to interact in a believable way. If you can think of any food, animal, household item, weapon, mythological creature, or vehicle, chances are you can make it appear. We're talking tens of thousands of possibilities. A few surprises can also be summoned, such as a variety of internet memes and special objects, if you can think of them.You can summon objects, or add adjectives to existing objects, to solve puzzles and make all the townspeople happy. Or, you could just screw around for hours summoning gods and beasts and riding them across the world as your epic mounts, or watching them run loose and terrorize the villagers. The puzzles are all ridiculously easy, but difficulty is obviously not the point. Personally, my favorite way to play this game is to think of the most obnoxiously ridiculous solutions to every puzzle. Most puzzles will have a bluntly obvious solution, but you can make hilarity ensue if you can think of something creative. For instance, a guy wanted something to help carve his ice sculpture. I gave him a toenail clipper. Hansel and Gretel needed something to make a trail with through the forest. I gave them thumbtacks. A buzzard wanted something to eat. I gave it a dead baby. A tracking dog needed something that smelled like Santa so he could search for Santa. I summoned Santa.It's an excellent game packed with great humor and content, and it's miles ahead of the Nintendo DS games it was based on. My only complaint is that it got a bit boring after the first few hours, but I fixed that just by taking some breaks and not playing it all on one sitting. But I never once stopped appreciating how wonderful the game is. Highly recommended for anyone who wants to rediscover their inner child, complete with borderline politically incorrect humor, in a way that very few games can provide. (Achievement hunters: getting 100% is very tedious, as you will need to solve over a hundred riddles to acquire the remaining bonus pieces. Usually you will solve some of them on accident throughout normal gameplay if you try to use creative solutions. However, if you ever get bored, you can just look at a FAQ to fully complete the game effortlessly.)

number of helpful: 67 of 72 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												"Write anything, solve everything." This has been the mantra for Scribblenauts since its creation in 2009, and each new installment comes closer and closer to realising this goal. Scribblenauts Unlimited on Steam has taken the "write anything" part to heart, but falters a bit of the "solve everything" side of the equation.The Steam Workshop support for this game is quite huge. If you can think of an object that the game doesn't recognise (mostly copyrighted content), then it's possible that someone has either created it for you, or some toying around with the game's impressive object editor will make your dreams a reality. Even better, you can upload your creations for all Steam users to enjoy.As awesome as this is, the gameplay is a tad disappointing. At least, we finally have an explanation for Maxwell's endless search for Starites (the game's MacGuffin). The story acts as a prequel to the series, as Maxwell struggles to retrieve the errant Starites to rescue his sister, Lilly (one of literally dozens of his relatives, all of whom are playable characters), from being turned into stone. This story is quickly forgotten once you start summoning vuvuzuela-playing pink jaguars to fight a winged preposterous black knight riding atop a cowardly telekinetic cybernetic T-rex, with only the occasional interlude reminding you of your main objective.To retrieve the Starites, Maxwell must help people around the game's expansive world with various problems, from helping an up-and-coming rock band gain a fanbase, to helping patients in a hospital with their various ailments. While its nice to have a large amount of different areas to explore, many of which feel alive with various characters mulling about, I couldn't shake the feeling that I was just playing nicer-looking versions of the DS games' title screens. Worse yet, many of the main challenges don't encourage your imagination as often as you think they would.Despite these problems, I would still highly recommend this game to anyone who hasn't played the series before. The visuals are crisp, the sheer amount of objects that can be generated is mind boggling (not counting the extensive Workshop creations), and it's still fun to see how each object and adjective interacts with each object in the world.------------------------------------------------------------------------------Pros:+ Graphics look amazing, even on low-powered laptops+ Amazing object editor+ "Write anything": only limited to your imagination+ Always fun to see object/adjective interactions+ Nice origin story for Maxwell...Cons:- ...but is quickly forgotten while goofing off- Worlds feel like glorified title screens from the DS games- Many challenges limit/stifle creativity

content:
Posted: November 13, 2013
												I highly recommend this fun for all ages kinda game. It is like mad libs come to life. You wander around what is basically a 2D open world mad libbing people's issues. Issues like I need something to scare away crows.... well just spawn a zombie or a scarecrow, or an angry hunter, or a gun to do it yourself! There's a lot of unintentional yet intentional fun here. Spawning a zombie to solve one puzzle might chase away other NPCs. Unless you add the adjective, friendly zombie. Its really the interactivity with the world that makes the game such silly fun. Did your zombie make a fire? Well have a firefighter put out that fire. Its a silly fun game that I can imagine would be great for kids. Simple controls that really thrive with a keyboard when you're typing things like 'pretty pink princess.'  There are good area settings too, everywhere from standard city areas like hospitals and a fire station, to more creative areas like Jurassic Park, a haunted house and a castle. Overall, the game is pretty easy. Easy enough that anyone can see it through to the end.

												A game with lots of creativity. You control a boy who can turn anything to life by writing it on his notebook. Lots of crazy things to do in this game like shooting down a building with "Destroyer", turning a lizard into a Ice Dragon and make him fight a "Flamethrower Soldier", building a school underwater, make a health potion and drink it if you are hurt and low on health, add dead as an adjective... content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												I am writing this review on behalf of my daughter, who recently completed the game. This is a wonderful game, for children and adults alike. For children, however, there is the added benefit of improving spelling and vocabulary as the child plays through the game. I know this, because my own child's vocabulary and spelling improved during the 140+ hours it took her to complete the game. It is relatively non-violent, that encourages the player to solve problems in creative and imaginative ways. There are often more ways than one to complete a challenge. Message to the developer: please make more follow-ups to this game! I'm aware of Scribblenauts Unmasked, although that game has much more fighting content in it than this one, so less violent solutions are not as viable. If the original dev won't make any more, I encourage anyone with the proper skill set to make more games like this; it's a winning formula that should not be abandoned.

Posted: October 2, 2015
Scribblenauts Unlimited is one of my favorite games in the Scribblenauts series. However... this is entirely because of the object creator and character creator.While I AM recommending this game, I feel the need to list a couple major issues I had with it:-The puzzles are much easier and less interesting/creative than the ones in Super Scribblenauts-They got rid of destructable terrain entirely (you can no longer dig/destroy the land like you could in Super Scribblenauts)-The maps are very crowded and there's no sandbox mode like there was in Super ScribblenautsAs you may have noticed, these are all downgrades from the previous Scribblenauts game (Super Scribblenauts), and while these issues do make the game a lot less fun, the new features mostly make up for it.I rate this game a 7.5/10 and recommend getting Super Scribblenauts if you have any of the devices it's available for.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												This game just makes me happy when I play it. It's fun and I laugh a lot while I play it. Do you really need anything else from anything? It's not a difficult game by any stretch as a simple story game of collecting stars to help save somethign from something with a lot of cool/cute art and object making. It lets you use your imagination to create an enormous amount of objects to just drop into the world and play with. Want a monkey? How about a GIANT monkey? You can make one and then ride it. Hilarious notebook? Sure. It will make every NPC that it passes by laugh. Create a Living Garden Gnome riding on a Tiny Goat. You can even create NPCs that will fight with one another, or even jsut play nice. Using adjectives in front of objects makes them even more interesting than they already are.You can save objects you create in your backpack for easy access, you can get objects created by other Steam users in the Workshop with simple in-game menus and a couple clicks. Tons of user created stuff is amazing and hilarious so make sure to spend a good amount of time in the Steam Workshop for this game. This is a Family Friendly game that anyone with a soul should play and enjoy. If you are a ginger, well we know you have no soul, but even YOU would probably be able to find some joy here. It's an easy 100% Achievements game and they just take the time of finishing all the stars mostly and making objects they tell you to. Trading cards as well of course. Fun and hilarious casual game for all ages!NOTE: If you look at the credits and use the Developer's names to create in-game characters they will all appear in the game with some sort of special attribute. One dev NPC has the ability to turn every hat you put on them to spawn wings that you can take and fly with for example. There are a ton of these and it is fun to mess around with. You can view the credits at any time so write down some developer names and experiment in the game. :)

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												Loved the original Scribblenauts games on the DS because of their simplicity and ease of access; everything was at your fingertips. Scribblenauts unlimited attempts to build on this formula by addding the feature of editing items already in the game world through adding modifiers. Unlimited also adds the ability to store items in your backpack for later use. All nice features, but altogether clunky as the game loses its charm without the use of a stylus. Having to mouse entirely across the screen to spawn in an item seems like a hassle when the first time around it took hardly any effort to access the notebook. It's still good ol' Scribblenauts, and while I'd take the old level select systems over this "open world" approach, Sribblenauts Unlimited is fun play and a creative pastime. 8/10

Posted: September 18, 2015
												This is truly a joy and not only because of the game. 5th Cell Media have developed a game that encourages thinking and learning and actually manages to pull something very fun and enjoyable in the process; something I haven't seen since the age of the Spectrum. Undoubtedly a child will find hours of fun trying to come up with wild and crazy adjectives to supplement their boring nouns. Equally they will perhaps try to find a not-so-obvious route to solve a problem, which again is a credit to the developers. Not enough games encourage this kind of learning and thinking while you play a game.

number of helpful: 37 of 54 people (69%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												The idea of Scribblenauts Unlimited really appealed to me. Using your own creativity to solve the hundreds and hundreds of puzzles without any limits. Unfortunately once i played a bit i started noticing more and more Scribblenauts isn't as unlimited as it claims to be. Now don't get me wrong Scribblenauts Unlimited is a very fun game and has some nice and creative locations you travel to! It runs really smooth and has almost no loading times at all. But the game is just really limited, often i tried solving puzzles in fun and creative ways and ended up on google asking myself why nothing works, with the dissapointing news you could only choose from a set of solutions the developers already choose. This way the game starts to feel like a chore after a while, just solving the puzzles with the most basic solutions because those are the only ones that work most of the time. Now this wouldn't be that bad if the puzzles would actually be challenging, but since this game is aimed more towards kids the puzzles are often so easy they're just boring. However Scribblenauts has some really nice and fun points aswell, you can costumize your own character and all of the different NPC's. And although the puzzles aren't as free as the game claims them to be, there are still quite a few items in the game to mess around with and you can create literally everything you can think of. The artstyle is unique and fits the game perfectly and the music is really catchy.Yes this game can be fun, especially for kids. And even i enjoyed this game, just not till the end cause it got way to repetitive after a while. Don't buy this and expect to get creative by solving the puzzles, buy this if you like solving basic and easy puzzles, don't mind a bit of repetitivty and enjoy messing around to create fun and original stuff.

												This is a really fun and original game that is easy to lose track of time on. I can't think of many games with gameplay that allows for so much variety, freedom, and creativity. Scribblenauts Unlimited is a good game. On the downside it does not have a whole lot of replay value. you can go back and enjoy it again, but eventually you feel like you have done it all. Ultimately it's a fun game that you will play, beat, and then probably leave alone. It's not a huge downside, not all games can have a whole lot of replay value, sometimes the way the games work does not make it very replayable.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												The concept of Scribblenauts is fantastic, and the graphics are awesome, but this game is really let down by how unbelievably easy the "puzzles" are. And yes, being creative is half the fun, but if puzzles are as easy as "oh no a pipe is leaking we need something to catch the water", or "my dog is hungry" then the novelty of something as strange as a pipe leaking into a swimming pool, or dogs eating enormous waffles wears off really quickly. What's more, an alarming number of the problems can literally be solved just by typing the word "gone", which takes another level of fun out of it.Everything else about this game is great, and I think it'd be fantastic for teaching kids about spelling and problem solving, but how unbelievably easy it is just ruins it completely for me. A few harder puzzles here and there, even if they were optional, would make this game infinitely more fun.

Posted: March 20
												When I got this game, I thought it was going to be similar to the first game I played on the DS, which I got bored with rather quickly. However, I was surprised at how far this franchise has come and how many hours I lost playing this quaint game. It inspires creativity, gets you thinking outside the box, if you choose, and can be very funny at points. The only downside, in my opinion, is that some of the solutions to some puzzles have a “guess what the dev’s thinking” mentality which, although makes the puzzles more challenging, can get a little annoying. Overall, a great game for people of any age and I recommend it highly.

number of helpful: 35 of 55 people (64%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 7, 2016
												Scribblenauts Unlimited is not a bad game. It's just not as good as I was hoping it would be. It's put together well, the artstyle is good, the soundtrack is good (I can still hear some of the game's music playing in my head,) and the voice acting (what little of it there is) is good. So where does it fall short, then? A few places actually. Let's start with the big one: the gameplay.The idea is to solve puzzles by conjuring up an object, or by adding an adjective to an existing one. Sounds intriguing, but really you just wind up solving puzzles with the most basic of objects. The whole idea of being able to add adjectives to objects is neat, but it's not really put into play all that much. There are a few instances where you must scare Person X away from Object/Person Y. So you just apply the adjective "Scary" to Object/Person Y. Or perhaps something needs wings, so you give it the adjective "Flying." Makes sense. But there's only a few puzzles that really make use of adjectives. The large majority of the puzzles can be solved with basic objects, and it just kinda starts to feel as though you're grinding through the game rather than really "solving" anything. It just gets rather tedious after a while.Then there's the Steam Workshop. Probably the main reason that the game is called Scribblenauts Unlimited, the way the Workshop works is you can use and in-game Object Editor to create your own objects and submit them to the workshop for the rest of the world to use. Likewise, you can download other people's creations. Now, I personally took one look at the Object Editor and said "No thanks." But I'm sure those of you out there who have the blood of Michelangelo or Vincent van Gogh coursing through your veins can imagine and create masterpieces with it. I just didn't feel like taking the time to get used to it.Now as for the Workshop itself. It's kind of...meh. There are some really well made and detailed things in there with their own creative and useful functions...surrounded by Five Nights at Freddy's characters. Don't get me wrong, I don't dislike Five Nights at Freddy's. I just dislike seeing it in every. Single. Workshop. However, you can play and enjoy the game without even looking at the Workshop, so I won't base my judgement of the whole game on it too much.Finally,considering the game's content and how many hours you'll likely get out of the game even if you go to the trouble of 100%ing it, that $20 price tag is WAY too much. To put it in perspective, you can purchase Terraria on Steam right now for $10. That's a game that you can potentially get hundreds of  hours out of. The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is a similar story: $15 for potentially hundreds of hours. Scribblenauts Unlimited meanwhile is $20 for around 12 hours if you feel so inclined to get all of the achivements. But to be fair, Terraria and The Binding of Isaac are COMPLETELY different than Scribblenauts. Scribblenauts isn't the type of game that you dedicate hundreds of your hours into. It's the kind of game that you finish, and then move on to something else. But even still...$20? In my opinion, if you truly feel so compelled to purchase the title, you're gonna want to wait until the next big sale.I hope this helps.

Posted: August 26, 2014
												A game with lots of creativity. You control a boy who can turn anything to life by writing it on his notebook. Lots of crazy things to do in this game like shooting down a building with "Destroyer", turning a lizard into a Ice Dragon and make him fight a "Flamethrower Soldier", building a school underwater, make a health potion and drink it if you are hurt and low on health, add dead as an adjective... Instant death! and more fun and crazy stuff to do. The art design is nice. And lots of variety in characters and customization. Its more like a sandbox game where you can do anything you want. Also has cool story. Its not a game for Everyone though. You might get bored of it quickly if you don't like these kind of games. And...! You can get past most of the game without killing people! Type "Sleepy" or "Sleeping" as adjective insteed! Had a great time in this game. Will play more.+ Creativity at Its Finest+ Great Art Design+ Lots of Characters and Customization+ Improve Your Spelling Skills! :P+ Good Story+ Makes You Think+ Truely Open World+ Lasts Long- Not for Everyone. Some People Might Get Bored of It Quickly- Resetting the Whole level After the Death of a Quest Related NPC for Level Completion. Respawn Feature Would Have Been Nice...

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
June 22, 2015Scribblenauts Unlimited is a strange game, functioning best as a sandbox to play with creativity and absurdity. Focusing on completing the game tasks can become boring, and a fair amount of objectives feel like padding. Completionists will be annoyed by the amount of chores needed to 100% the game.This may sound like the game is bad, and that could be argued. Approached as a series of tasks to save Lily, the game can feel a bit slow. However, sometimes you need to forget the quests and just mess around. Arm shotguns with shotguns, then hand them to a musical afro. Build a tower of dirty jesters, riding a hated jester on the bottom. Give a dog-fearing man a dog whistle and watch him panic. Play around, and you can really see the pure fun of this game. I've spent at least an hour catching my breath after hilarious events, most of which I didn't expect or plan. That alone is worth the time and money, in this era of pretentious art games and multiplayer communities that make you hate humanity.Do you want to laugh, preferably without vulgarity? Can you come up with some silly ideas to see what happens? I'd recommend Scribblenauts Unlimited.  I don't have much idea about the Unmasked version, doesn't seem to change much beyond the missions, and I figure the Unlimited Workshop community is stronger. I got the game from a Humble Bundle key  <3 Fred but I would recommend the game easily at 25% off for $15 USD.

												This game is clever, innocent and fun. My seven-year-old neighbor begs me to let him play some Scribblenauts all of the time, and I definitely love this game as much as him. content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												Scribblenauts Unlimited is a game where you create stuff, earn Starites by completing objectives, and play as any character you want. You can create anything. Anything! Like Shoggoth, a squirrel, a T-Rex, Deadpool, a lighthouse, and even a leprechaun. The object of the game is to get 60 Starites. Once you hit 60, you've completed the game and you get to play as Maxwell's sister, Lily. Hooray! You can create stuff using the object editor. Like a cat launcher, a cat gun, an army camouflage rifle, Ellen DeGeneres, etc. You can also create your own avatar if you want, and you can download other people's creations on your Steam Workshop. They can create other stuff and upload them on their Steam Workshop too.I recommended this game. I like it.

												Likes:It it freaking hilarious!!! I can sit and play this thing for hours on end!The ability to manipulate anything and everything in the game just makes for a very special gaming experience, and even though this game is targeted at a (much) younger audience than myself, I find it to be plenty stimulating and intriguing.I can imagine this would be a great game for your kid learning colors and words, and grammars and stuff (yes, I see what I did there).Now, with English not being my primary language, I learn a lot of new things through this game, and I like how I am sort of forced to learn words I rarely or never use in daily life.The absolute major +++3000 for me about this game is the manipulation of everything, and the possibility to download mods to make it (less) childproof and more to my liking.Dislikes:... number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												For me, playing Scribblenauts Unlimited is a very entertaining way to touch and play a little with my inner child! For those who play it, everything seems like a simple logic problem that must be solved with a bunch of creativity. The fact the game has a simple and at the same time full of imaginative possibilities mechanic, which matches with the clean artwork and graphics, drives the player to this very wished psychological place of not worrying or not having to follow any kinds of protocols, by fullfiling complex and hard-to-understand objectives; but yet being driven and carried on by such direct and fundamental moral themes: making other people a little happier with the powers we have and struggling to undo an "evil" caused by our own acts. With the nowadays tendence of creating very human like heroes and villains, with a spectrum of mixed moral values and affections, Scribblenauts makes us all remeber a little what is like to have possibilities of believing and making things look and feel better without the need of titanic actions and moves. I have a 10 here, but that's likely because I really like to hang around with the kiddo side of myself!

content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												This is one of my favorite games. However, it has its flaws. If you dont want to read this entire review, scroll all the way to the bottom, There's a tl;dr version.So first off, the title lies.The object creator is limited. The fact that it says "Unlimited" in the title makes it feel like the creator just wants money. It really takes alot of the fun away from the game, but don't get me wrong. I know it was made in 2012 and making everything "Unlimited" would kill your computer's memory, but this still is pretty dissapointing.Basically, my point is; Don't buy the game unless you know what to expect, or you've played the game before on something like the Wii U.Second, the small space in all of the levels.I haven't played through the entire game yet, but im getting there. What really bothers me more than the limited object creator is that the levels are just so small.If you've only played things like Big RPGs, Shooters, and Garry's Mod, then this game is going to be weird for you.Although each level has enough space for you to create several things, the free space could be bigger.Finally, the price is too high.I don't think this game's worth 20$. Like i mentioned earlier, the game's very limited and not what you'd expect. Please, take a moment to think about it before you buy it. Now, lets go to the positives.First off, the artstyle's unique.Yes, it's a little blocky and chibi-ish, but it just works. That's all i need to say for this.Second, you can create almost anything you want.You can write something bad like "Invincible Strong Huge Bee" and it'll appear as an invincible strong huge bee. If its not in the game, you can make it.Third, the gameplay.The missions, the fact that you can create almost anything, and the high resolution is just what you'd expect from a Scribblenauts game.Finally, that feeling you get when playing Scribblenauts.The feeling of wondering "When will there be another game?"10/10. Tl;dr: The game's limited, the levels are too small, and the price is too high. But the artstyle's unique, you can create almost anything you want, and the feeling of wondering "When will there be another game?" While playing this. 10/10

content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												Imagine being able to create whatever you wanted just by writing it in a book. Now, instead of using this book to give yourself a flying rainbow llama, you use it to help people in need. This is Scribblenauts Unlimited, the third game in the Scribblenauts series.You play as Maxwell, a young boy who has been given the gift of a magic notebook from his parents. Maxwell then uses the notebook to give a rotten apple to a hungry man, and angers him. The man puts a curse on Lily, his sister, who now slowly turns to stone. To stop this, Maxwell has to make up for his trickery by collecting Starites from people, to free his sister from the curse.The gameplay in Scribblenauts Unlimited is basic, but it is obtained and used well. I was never confused by the controls or wandered around pressing buttons. The notebook feature is easy to use, and writing something with multiple meanings (say, 'bat') will bring up a menu to select which type of object you would like. There is also a backpack feature that allows you to save your favourite creations for easier access later, but I rarely used this feature as I created new and different things all of the time.While Scribblenauts Unlimited is simple, its charming art style is colourful, playful and different to a lot of other games that I am used to. Playing the first two games on the Nintendo DS, Scribblenauts Unlimited combines the series-defining mechanics of the first game with the creativity and art style of Super Scribblenauts, building a game that is definitely one of the best puzzle games available on PC. While this game is definitely directed towards a younger audience, I couldn't help but pick up the third instalment of this amazing franchise.There are no borders in Scribblenauts Unlimited. Unlike the first two games, Scribblenauts Unlimited is set it over 20 different locations, which when unlocked are accessible all the time, creating an open world to explore and invent wonderful contraptions and experiments. Never in any other game have I seen so much creative freedom.To conclude, Scribblenauts Unlimited is a flawless addition to the series, and definitely a game that will consume a fair amount of play time.9.8/10

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
Scribblenauts Unlimited is an adventure puzzle game. As Maxwell, save your sister Lily from a curse by creating happiness around the world with the use of your magical notepad that can create anything you can write.Pros: The game has an astonishing amount of potential content. Almost any word and adjective you can think of, you can create by typing it. There is a lot of different method to resolve any situation, and the fun comes in finding new and unexpected ways to do so. You will find yourself attempting different solutions again and again even after you already succeeded just to see if you can find an easter egg or game secret. Usable created objects also add game elements to work with, and combining people or objects with one or more adjectives increases the possibilities tenfold.Cons: The game is short, you can breeze through it, getting the Starites you need to win the game within a few hours. Many of the puzzles are easy, half of which can usually be resolved with the same few objects. There are multiple passageways to move around a level, but they are often useless as it won't take time for you to always make sure you have a jet-pack or pair of wings to move around. Unless you want to explore the possibilities, you won't find much replayability as resolving a puzzle in different ways still ends up with the exact same result.Verdict: ★★★★☆ - Next on your list!If you're looking for an exciting story, grand adventure or mind-bending puzzles, turn away. But if you're looking for an entertaining time trying to push the limit of the game, and exploring just how far you can go, it's a great one. The Steam Workshop makes it easier than ever to add dozens, if not hundreds of new objects and options, assuming you don't use the object creator to add your own. Furthermore, the game is great for all ages, maybe even more so for younger gamers. Of course, if you didn't like previous Scribblenauts games, you're unlikely to enjoy this one. But if you did, Scribblenauts Unlimited will go where previous ones never went before!—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

Posted: April 6, 2015
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

												An experience not far detached from genuine creative writing, except you get your vocabulary hacked off at the knees, turning it (and - subsequently - you) into a linguistically-challenged, clean-mouthed, experimental dwarf. The upside is that instead of crawling under your desk to cry about your lack of progress and insistence on unhealthy quantities of procrastination, your efforts are rewarded with charming caricatures rendered in glorious patches of primary colour.  In all fairness, it's a tempting trade-off.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												5th Cell have made a few very good games that I have played, and this is one of them. This game company has made a few games that can really inspire creativity, such as Drawn To Life and Scribblenauts, though of course inspire creativity  in different ways.Scribblenauts is a game that encourages you to come up with ways to solve moderatly easy puzzles, where there is no one solution. Because there is no one solution, it has high replay value, with you figuring out what else works, and different ways to do the same thing. At first you might start out summoning a sponge to clean a wall, later you will be using aardvarks for everything. This game has changed a lot since it's start on the Nintendo DS, and you can even MAKE new things with parts of things from the game, and even script their behaviour! Or if you are no good at making things, you can download some from the Steam Workshop!There are very few flaws in this game, as no game is perfect. One flaw I find is not really a flaw, but can be seen as one, you have way too much freedom in this game. Limits really work well in certain games, and with games with too much freedom you can get bored, or you see no challenge. If you get bored, there are heaps of achievements to get and there are little challenges in-game for you to solve. But if you have done everything, you can always clear the game data and start anew, and maybe even have a challenge of your own, like, for example, only using aardvarks, which is something I find myself doing a lot.This game doesn't just stop at the limitless freedom, it also has a very heartwarming story, that premotes kindness. Which is a very nice touch on top of the rest of the game. These types of games are very hard to come across, they are very different from most games, and because they are different and very special, they are games that you must have, even if you are a gamer who plays zombie games, or plays a lot of indie games (a lot of the time they overlap) you must have this, as it is not just another generic game, it is Scribblenauts Unlimited.

												The game features the most awesome mercenaries in the galaxy in their fight for territorial supremacy. Scribblenauts brings Russian monkeys with jetpacks, giant robots, and lots of other mighty aliens to the two-dimensional console battlefield. number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												This is one of my favorite games of all time.  I often play it whenever I need cheering up.It has lackluster reviews, and I've noticed almost everyone that rates it mediocre or bad plays it differently than I do.  You could consider this both a review and a guide to having fun with the game.  Don't worry, there won't be spoilers.If you're out of elementary school, and play the game in the most straightforward way, it will be too easy.  It amounts to a graphical adventure where you can access almost every item in the game by typing the name, letting you bypass anything resembling a puzzle.  While this might be viewed as a problem by teenagers and adults playing the game, it's actually a good thing for children, who can use it as a fun way to exercise their vocabulary skills.Teenagers and adults playing the game should use their creativity.  The game is usually surprisingly flexible in how you can achieve a goal.  The only restrictions it normally has are: you can't use real people's names, or anything involving drugs, prejudice, or sex, and you often can't kill anybody.Suggestions to get you started: Be indirect.  Creating things people ask for and sticking adjectives on the problem is boring.  Create other beings and complex Rube Goldberg contraptions made of multiple objects to solve problems.  Watch the chaos as unexpected interactions ensue!  When your solutions cause more problems, add more elements to try to fix those, rather than changing or removing anything. Be lazy.  See how little you can create while still solving a problem indirectly.  This usually involves heavy use of side effects.  You may be able to solve multiple problems on the same level with one action. Be impractical.  Pick a role and stubbornly stick to it.  The best roles are those least suited to a hero (e.g. cook, janitor, tailor…).  Dress the part and give yourself appropriate adjectives.  Try to solve all problems using only things that are in theme.  MacGyver would be proud. Do no harm.  When dealing with a problematic creature or object, try to create and use some other creatures or objects that harmlessly neutralize it, rather than fighting or destroying it. Provide unhelpful help.  Be an evil genie.  Do what someone asked you to do, but make sure it has side effects they won't like, or doesn't achieve their goal. Consider what would happen if…  For example, what would happen if a prince, turned into a frog, was given a werewolf princess to kiss?Played this way it should have you laughing your head off.  You may lose the level (usually due to an accidental death), but have so much fun you won't care.The game does have some flaws.It doesn't recognize every correctly spelled word.  That would have been impossible to program and create art for.Some goals are too restrictive to allow creativity.  Sometimes there is only one solution.  There should be at least three significantly different solutions.  Better playtesting could have caught this.There are “fetch quests”.  They involve going to some part of the map, which is usually unobstructed, picking up a item, and carrying it back to the person that asked for it.  You can't use your magical notebook to do this, and it's unhumorous, uncreative, and unchallenging.  Hopefully the authors will stop including these in the future.While I love what the object editor can do, I hate how it does it.  The primary pain-point is how difficult it is to “draw” a new object.  You have to do it by lumping together existing art assets.  The second worst pain-point is how difficult it is to get the behavior you want.  You can only create new behaviors by tuning settings on existing ones.  While you can argue this is “creative problem solving”, it fits poorly with the design of the rest of the game.  Making a item in game is as easy as typing the name.  Making items in the object editor should be similarly painless.  We'd be better off with a design that imports SVG and allows scripting in some common, efficient, sandboxable, programming language, like JavaScript or Lua.There is no way to create new levels at all.  This could have greatly extended interest in the game.Overall, I think this is one of the finest games ever made, and look forward to more in the series.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												Great little game, it's got a ridiculous amount of adjectives. You can spawn an evil version of yourself that randomly creates things to see how advanced it is, you'll see things like "noctophilic haystack" or "serendipitous pho." They use lots of playtesters to see what solutions people would come up with so that combined with lots of items fitting into similar categories means that most puzzles have an incredible amount of solutions. Spawn a pregnant man and a midwife and you'll get a thin man and a baby man, for example. I don't know how that helps solve puzzles, but there's a lot of dynamic events that pop up. It's worth a look and you can buy it, get a feel for it and return it within 2 hours if you don't like it. That's more than enough time to see what the game is like and whether you want to keep playing, after the opening cutscene and tutorial, you're essentially thrown into the game and have all your abilities. The only downside is the Steam Workshop, which is really cool. Lots of... interesting things there but the only way I've found it to work is that you have to subscribe to things from the game itself, that's the only way it would load what you want. I would've also liked to be able to use downloaded models for the character selector but I suppose the detailed character creator is a more configurable tool. Still, it's nigh impossible to pick Jango Fett or Samus as your character unless you know what you're doing.

Posted: September 22, 2015
												This game is two-faced.On the one hand there's the nice Maxwell saving his sister Lily by helping people (and other things) do stuff they otherwise couldn't do.On the other hand, there's hostile Gods shooting with Uzis at evil floating potatoes and radioactive lettuce while these are throwing grenades at them, nuclear keyboard cats chasing firetrucks, swimming radios with scary masks, undead outlets ending up in a lake and extincting all living things inside, and everything else is either sucked in by a huge black hole or touched by Death while you're cloning some massive huge strong wide tall soldiers for the upcoming Martian invasion.(Oh I almost forgot the Steam Workshop and the object editor, which stretch the possibilities for your own personal havoc to infinity. Have your own personal Pokémon Trainer battle, scare Doges away with a scarecrow that has Bonnie's face, or set up a death battle Sanic vs. Weegee on Final Destination.)It's up to you which side you want to choose. But it's pretty clear what your copy of the game will mostly be used for... isn't it? ;)

												This is a game that I found myself addicted to during the first few hours of playing.  The creative aspect of the game is really fun and it really encourages you to come up with creative ways to complete each task.  As with a lot of the other reviews, you can come up with the most ridiculous solutions to the tasks and still pass them.  Spawning random objects just to mess around with the NPCs is probably one of the most entertaining things about this game as well.  Despite all of this, the story could get boring after a while, but it is a fun game to play nonetheless.  I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who is interested in creative type games like this.

												I'd definitely recommend this game to anyone looking for a quirky, inventive, and open little game to play around with. Despite seeming like a childish game as it may to some people, there is a plethora of references to movies, songs, shows, mythology, historical events, Shakespeare, etc. which must be understood in order to complete certain quests. number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												It is unlikely you will find a single scenario in this game that will challenge you to think outside the box.  Most of the problems the game presents you with can be solved in painfully obvious ways.  Do you need to put out a fire? Type fireman.  Is someone  hungry?  Give them food.  Because of this most of the fun in the game will be through either self imposed challenges such as not allowing yourself to solve things in a obvious way or by trying to solve everything in a silly or ironic way.  I myself tried to complete as much of the game as possible using the noun "baby" with different adverbs attached to it (this worked surprisingly well). Despite its flaws I would still recommend the game if you enjoy sandbox experiences as with the addition of steam workshop it has enormous potential in that area. Just don't buy it expecting a challenging puzzle game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												Scribblenauts is great. Its even better if you play by your own rules and have an audience. If you don't know the basic idea is there are people who need the help of your godlike notebook that can create anything you can imagine and write down into it. So this knight needs a weapon to fight off a giant dragon, why not give him a diamond chainsaw? This girl wants to win a race, why not make her a super hero with super speed? Want to ride around on a golden dinosaur or a flying magical cat? Well in Scribblenauts you can. Its a little easy to get tired of the game though. Its fun and all but the overall difficulty can basically be summed up in "this mouse wants cheese, click notebook write cheese, give cheese to mouse. This football team can't play football without a football.. click on notebook write football, give football to team." ..its absurd how easy the game is. Every once in a while I got totally stuck on something because its a childrens rhyme or a kids logic thing that I am obviously no longer in the loop for but that can be solved with a good audience.The real fun though comes from messing with the game. So the mouse wants cheese right? Why not give him a cat made out of cheese then watch the hilarity of a mouse eating a live cheese cat. That poor guy needs a doctor, why not give him a zombie doctor? Make it fun and it becomes fun.. let it be boring and it can really tire you out. Overall its a great game and its easy to 100% (though you'll probably want a walkthrough for the random object challenges). I think it would be great to play with others more than alone and children maybe more than adults.. but its a great game for all ages.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												For a child     I can see why a child needs this game. It has hard puzzles for a growing mind and allow you to solve them with your creativity. Also something that allows you to make your own objects! That is awesome, but the community got a little carried away with that. I will go in more detail later. Back on subject, this game might not have a sandbox mode where you can't die. Scibblenauts Unlimited replaces that with a massive world to explore. Makes you feel like you are helping real people instead of just doing levels. Fun new graphics, expertly done, endless hours, and most of all real characters that you feel for. This game is better then the old one indeed.     Now to complain.   This game has a awful community. Be warned! See the workshop items section below. All items are just stupid and you know why. Here they are...10% normal fun items25% stupid items like cat hydras, baby guns, or worse.35% Fnaf items, how did scibblenauts get fnaf disease? Also pokemon too.30% Adult jokes, There is balls items and nudity everywhere!     As you see 90% is just bad. That is only complaint.My final score is a 97%, but the community brings it to a 80%.The rating is 10+, but because of that I bring it to a 13+ game.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												I've tackled games in this series before on nds and iphone but this one seems to be the one with the most content...which is both good and bad really. I've waited for this to come out for a while and while it's actually really fun that wears off after a while. While every new are you go to is interesting and uniwue in it's own right they all follow the same rules - you have different characters with problems and you have to come up with an item or a person that will solve that. This is really fun at first but it can get repetitive after a while and getting all the starites in the game (you get starites or shards for every problem you solve) is very tedious.Bottom line play it in small doses and it will stay fun...try to complete it all at once and it will get pretty boring. Also it's fun to screw the goals of the game and just do whatever - make a pink cthulhu with a rainbow colored afro fight a robot elephant with gatling guns. If you can think it you can pretty much make it in this game..and then set it on fire and launch it in space.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												When the original Scribblenauts came out for the DS, it was one of my favorite games. While it did not have the option to customize objects or use adjectives, most levels were both fun and challenging, forcing you to push your creativity's limits in order to reach the starite. Scribblenauts Unlimited allows much more depth with creating items, but the levels/puzzles do not reach beyond simply creating a category of object when prompted. There are no action levels in Scribblenauts Unlimited and as a result none of the levels are really challenging and there is no satisfaction in completing them. The object editor also allows you to create overpowered objects as well, decreasing what little challenge there is. It is fun to fool around with the object editor, but Scribblenauts Unlimited does not offer much depth beyond customizing your own objects.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												Scribblenauts Unlimited was a gift to me.  I had heard about the game winning awards, but never considered it "my kind of game."  The basic premise is that you are a child with a magical notebook that allows anything you draw to come to life.  n You use the notebook to help people in town in order to save your sister who was randomly cursed.  You can type thousands of things into this notebook, and they will pop up on the screen.  The beauty of the game is in the sense of humor and in all the unexpected interactions that the people in the game have with the items you create. (I may have created a citywide epidemic by modifying a cockroach with the adjective "diseased," but that's not important...)  It took me a little bit to get the hang of what the game expected of me and a couple of hilarious discussions with my roomie ("What would you draw in order to make a lamb come to dinner?"  Him: "What?") to fully grasp it all, but I really enjoyed the creativity and imagination that the game offered.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2013
												This is a great puzzler where, to use a cliché, the only limit is your imagination - within the boundaries of PG. I would recommend it to you if you've never played a Scribblenauts game before or if you just want a good puzzle game. There's a few hours of story in it, plus the added bonus of the sandbox mode, which is essentially integrated into the story. It's jam-packed full of recognizable references includingNyan Cat, Lord of the Rings, Super Mario, Indiana Jones and Half Life. It also has something called the Object Editor which allows you to create your own items to use in the game and even upload to the Steam Workshop. You can also download some great content put out by other users too. It's definitely targeted to a younger demographic but that doesn't mean older gamers won't get something out of it too.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												A fun, quirky game about a boy with omnipotence, and easily the best game on the series. It's also on the Wii U/3DS but you should actually get it on steam because workshop compatibility. It's not truly unlimited, but it certainly reaches far into it's possibilities. Also has the most powerful character in every game. The only thing I don't really like is all the epick maymay references, but you may do, who am I to judge you. Also keep in mind this is an E rated game so no, you won't be able to spawn a beer or something, unless you create it on the object creator.Now, If you're looking for a real challenging puzzle, Scribblenauts will not deliver. It's puzzles may go from no brainer "give me an X" to something like a riddle, but overall not an actual puzzle game. If you want a puzzle scribblenauts, I'd suggest the original one for the DS, this one is more of a creator based scribblenaut, rather than a puzzle based one. If you want to purchase scribblenautss unlimited for the creativity factor and the adventure and other stuff that isn't puzzles, go ahead.

												Worth $5 at most. Nice quick and short game(about 10 hours game-play at most.) and basically, you type an object, it appears. I wouldn't recommend it at full-price but no worries, it goes on sale quite often.

content:

												For a kids game it's pretty good. It gives you some good moral lessons and helps expand your vocabulary, sometimes i had to look into a dictionary to find a really good word to solve some puzzles. Anyways let's get down to gameplay, you play a character named Maxwell and you have to help your sister from turning into stone that was casted by a mysterious stranger and in order to turn her back to normal you have to collect these stars called starrites. In order to get starrites you have to solve peoples problems the more problems you solve the more starrites you get. You write in a notebook to solve problems so anything you write in there becomes a reality, what i mean by this is that anything you write in the book rather it be person,place,or thing appears right in front of you. You can pretty much write anything in there except vulgarity,copyright material, or if you can help it not write the same words over and over again.After playing this game for 9 hours i would recommend this to anyone who is creative with words.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												     Scribblenauts Unlimited is a VERY fun installation in the Scribblenauts series.  New to the game is the object editor, a very easy to use and creative way of making your own interactive objects.  You can change sizes, colors, and shapes, but the one thing that made me upset was that you can't DRAW your own objects.  This limits you to using only pre-made things in the game, forcing you to combine them if you want something unique.      Also new to Scribblenauts is its vast world.  From the city, to a desert, and even to space, you can take Maxwell (or one of his many brothers) on missions around the virtual globe.  Each level has challenges awaiting you that can be very simple or complex.  On the other hand, many missions have simple solutions.  For example, if a boy is unhappy, you can make a clown, video game, etc.  The possibilities are endless, but the entertainment level with some obstacles is limited.     All in all, I still like playing the game.  Even after you finish all the side-missions and campaign, you can still make your own objects and re-create your favorite characters and scenes from movies, video games, and books.  I highly recommend this game for anyone who wants to share their ideas with others and explore Maxwell's world.

												The initial humor and creativity lies in finding strange ways to solve problems.  Why just build an airplane when you can give yourself wings?  And how many imaginary creatures can you make?  But as the game goes on, you'll find yourself using the same objects for the many identical challenges. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2013
												This is a great puzzler where, to use a cliché, the only limit is your imagination - within the boundaries of PG. I would recommend it to you if you've never played a Scribblenauts game before or if you just want a good puzzle game. There's a few hours of story in it, plus the added bonus of the sandbox mode, which is essentially integrated into the story. It's jam-packed full of recognizable references includingNyan Cat, Lord of the Rings, Super Mario, Indiana Jones and Half Life. It also has something called the Object Editor which allows you to create your own items to use in the game and even upload to the Steam Workshop. You can also download some great content put out by other users too. It's definitely targeted to a younger demographic but that doesn't mean older gamers won't get something out of it too.

The dual screen cult classic is BACK on your mouse and keyboard.Men in variety of settings want things with [property]. 												Brilliant game. Seriously brilliant. Ostensibly a puzzle solving game but this is really a playground for your childhood imagination. Figuring out the most creative ways to accomplish something, in a way that shouldn't be possible outside of a pencil and paper, is just so very, very satisfying. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												The basic gameplay of Scribblenauts is solving little puzzles by creating objects that you can then use to manipulate the world. Most of the puzzles are very straightforward, and allow the player to come up with many different solutions, but every now and then I would get stuck on something. Usually it was because the answer the game was looking for was something completely different than I was thinking, so it was unable to interpret how the objects I created were supposed to be a solution. So while the game is pretty smart considering you can input thousands of words, sometimes it just balks and has no idea what you're trying to do.That said, it's still amazingly fun. There is a map where you can select different levels, each of which you can explore. Each zone has a funny theme, named with a funny grammar pun. The characters that you have to help are often silly and almost always endearing.Steam achievements: Half of them are completed by being a completionist and making sure you finish every detail in every level. But then the other half of the achievements... don't seem to be listed anywhere. I had to go online to figure out what "find all the object shards" entailed. It was basically a list of special word combinations, and if you spawned them together, or made the items interact with each other, then it counted toward the total score. For instance, one required you to make a marionette with the adjective "alive" to get the "Pinocchio" object shard. How in the world are you supposed to figure that out on your own? I needed a guide to figure out what I was looking for, but I didn't want to just run down a cheat sheet, so I searched for a guide that was simply a list of the object shards without the solutions. That was extremely helpful to get the achievements without feeling like a complete cheater. I looked and could not find a list like this anywhere within the game itself. If there is one in the game, it was pretty darn hidden, which is frustrating.(Also, the game says you cannot type in proper nouns. However, one of the object shards requires you to create "William Shakespeare". The last time I checked, that was a proper noun. What? Okay, whatever.)Object editor: So much fun! I didn't do much editing myself, what with my limited artistic skills. But when I found an avatar with 3D glasses, I dyed all of his clothes brown (except for the shoes, of course) and ran around the game, going, "Woooo, I'm the Doctor!"You can also search for and download other objects that people have created. I downloaded a bunch of Doctor Who objects. I was amazed at the amount of customization people were able to put into the objects, from a piece of celery inside of the TARDIS, to a banana in 9's hand, to the combatitiveness of a dalek. I had a great amount of fun playing with these items that other people had created with the object editor.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												I admire the vast selection of things you can create in this game and the unique level designs that each have their own personalities ranging from a Prehistoric utopia to a space base. Normally a game like Scribblenauts wouldn't be my cup of tea as it's a pretty casual game in all honesty and it did become repetitive at times. However, it was a decent enough playthrough thanks to just the sheer amount of creativity invested into the game.  I could tell Scribblenauts is aimed at a younger audience and the plot is pretty typical but let's face it, people don't play scribblenauts for an intricate plot it's very gameplay heavy. I'd reccomend Scribblenauts to younger gamers in particular and just anybody that wants to kill some time without investing too much into a series.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												The thing I love about this game is that the possibilities are endless. You can make almost anything and what's not programmed into the game you can make yourself or download from other users though Steam. Unlimited is definitely a most fitting title.Another brilliant thing about Scribblenauts is that it can be enjoyed by any age group. Some might think this game is childish but it is so enjoyable.The style is colourful and friendly and you don't have to worry about hoards of monsters coming at you. I think there should be more relaxed, casual games like this.I'd say the main are Scribblenauts Unlimted falls down is language. The only language option in this game is English. That said, I imagine a game based on writing would be rather difficult to translate.All in all, I highly reccommend this game.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												This is a very unique puzzle game. The art is bright and colorful and the environments are fun and well drawn up. The puzzles are creative and interactive although they can be quite simple at times, especially once you find out what I like to call (Cheat items) these are items that allow you to do many of the puzzles with ease, one of these such items is Wings. Speaking of items, the amount of things you can type and create is insanely impressive and makes it so you have so you have a variety of objects that can help in each puzzle meaning that you may even solve the puzzle differently or with a different item then someone else did. Its very kid friendly but is also very fun as an adult and could even be something cool to play with you kid if thats what your looking for. Highly recommended as it is just a unique charming puzzle game that is very addictive, has loads to do in it and the art work is just gorgeous.Game Showcase/ Gameplay-

												This game is one of my favourite games to play, i would really recommend this to anyone with an imagination and that needs a good laugh. You have a magic notebook that can create anything you want and the fun part is you can play around in the world with it or also try and get starites from around the world. The storyline itself is about a couple that love to go on adventures together and were happy together they ended up having a lot of children and passed on the thrill for adventure to the children but one day the only girl of the family meets a wizard who tricks her and turns her into stone the only way to save her? starites throughout the world as soon as you complete the world she gets better. It's a very cute game and i really enjoyed playing it! i  think everyone should give it a chance i'm sure you would find something funny or amusing to do in the game! :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2013
												It almost seems like attaching the adjectives 'charming', 'gentle' or 'lovely' to a description of this game might be damning with faint praise. After all, wholesomeness only goes so far, right? Well, luckily that's not really the case. Scribblenauts IS charming, gentle and lovely and it manages to be all of those things without tipping towards the sickly, saccharine and ultimately bland and nauseating end of the spectrum. Part of this comes down the player throwing themselves into the spirit of the game. For someone who has no problem negotiating play time with their inner child, the game is a treat: relaxing, witty, occasionally quite puzzling, and offering up possibilities for creative solutions at every turn. And, y'know, when a game is that completely pleasant it also makes it all a lot more fun. Good game.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2013
												Ever wanted to have the power supreme, being able to materialize anything you could think of at a moment's notice? Annoyed with adventure games that reject your awesome solutions to the puzzles simply by not giving you the desired items? If you answered Yes to both, then Scribblenauts is for you. It encourages many ways to go about the challenges, or just wreak havoc on your fellow man, while still promoting creativity, and even if you are not that savvy about correct spelling, you might even learn something with this. Even if you try to be witty at first, it may be a while until you find something that is not in the game's vocabulary, apart from obscenities and copyrighted materials of course. And best of all, the visuals and characters as well as the music score are adorably cute!

content:
Posted: January 14, 2014
												"Help me escape without the guard noticing!"Okaaay... [*Type* Morphine] How about that.*picks up, smothers guards face, guard sleeps, guy escapes*wait... that actually worked?"Dude, I need help delivereing pizza, can you give me a sweet ride?"Sure, um... [*Type* Rocketship] merry Christmas*Enters rocket, grabs pizza, blasts away* Thank yooouuu......wait... that actually worked?!I need a weapon... something cool... [*Type* small purple katar] can you do THAT?*weapon similar to Voldo's from soulcalibur appears, the size of my fist and purple*THAT ACTUALLY WORKED?!?!Everytime I typed something the game had something to give me, which blew me away. The possibilities are endless; it would take me weeks to figure out all the graphics the designers shoved into the dicionary. Obscure things like decahexane tetrachloride would actually yield results. If you wanna type Laser Rifle, that would work, or if you type a pew pew pew, you'll still get an alien gun. The level of vocabulary is so diverse. The only things it doesn't have are propernouns/copywrited material, obviously, or they might have to type Lawyer, and there's no profanity/adult content, which actually is pretty funny when you type♥♥♥♥♥and a donkey appears. The flaw to this game is that the main story only has a very limited number of hours to the gameplay, even if you go on to do notebook challenges. Unless you find it enjoyable to simply make your own stuff and play around in a sandbox (A massive one), which I do, you probably won't get more than 10-20 hours out of it, unless you're a child.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												It's casual.  And open world.  And it invokes creativity.  And it is even intelligent in certain aspects.  However, perhaps the main feature that makes this game really neat is because although it gives an ample selection of pre-created objects & NPCs in any given part of the game's world, you can create practically anything imaginable using your Notepad, and then add in-game "Adjectives" that describe the object and will alter its behavior.  To top it off, this amazing game comes complete with Steam Workshop support, so you can share your fun creations with others and utilize their content in your own gameplay.  Definately recommend you try it!

												Played scribblenauts on the DS and it was amazing.Played the sequel and it got better.Played this, it could've been better.Scribblenauts unlimited is not a bad game, far from it. It's a good game but the only thing that made me sad is that they dumbed it down a bit. I like the free exploring through the world, create an object is fun and the starites do have humor in it.What i really miss is the diffeculty that the DS games had(wings and jetpacks were less OP as well).The starite missions are fun for its objectives and the humor it shows, the starite shards are also nicely done.Both starite and starite shard objectives have references to other things to make it even more complete.Overall Scribblenauts is a nice game to buy, it's well worth the price. If you don't like the price, just wait for a sale to come up.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												Scribblenauts is, to put it bluntly, a puzzle sandbox.  If you can think of whatever could be used to solve a puzzle (or not), you can type it's name and summon it.  This game also includes adjectives, so you can write "explosive rainbow bacon" and get just that.  If the game cannot summon it, just hop on over to the workshop and see what others have made, or make it yourself with the painlessly easy object creator/editor.  Suddenly you've got yourself a nuclear bacon launcher and catgirl with the face of an elder god in the game.  It's extremely easy and wholly entertaining to ignore the main game and wreak utter havoc with what you summon.  The game makes you the closest thing to a physical god as possible, so go completely nuts.

												Played scribblenauts on the DS and it was amazing.Played the sequel and it got better.Played this, it could've been better.Scribblenauts unlimited is not a bad game, far from it. It's a good game but the only thing that made me sad is that they dumbed it down a bit. I like the free exploring through the world, create an object is fun and the starites do have humor in it.What i really miss is the diffeculty that the DS games had(wings and jetpacks were less OP as well).The starite missions are fun for its objectives and the humor it shows, the starite shards are also nicely done.Both starite and starite shard objectives have references to other things to make it even more complete.Overall Scribblenauts is a nice game to buy, it's well worth the price. If you don't like the price, just wait for a sale to come up.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Honestly, i was sceptical about playing Scribblenauts Unlimited.It looks simple enough, but does not look like my 'type' of game. Keeping an open mind I gave it a go!I was impressed!The game has you completing hundred of tasks ranging in difficulty and hilarity.You are equipped with a notepad which enables you to create just about anything, and add adjectives to objects and people!One task asks you to dispose of toxic waste in a better manner than being dumped on the sea floor.So i pulled out my note book, equipped myself with a rifle and shot the barrels up. They disappeared and task was accomplished.It's even just fun to mess with different adjectives and objects. I took a lion, a basic lion, added some wings, added adjectives 'massive, scary' and it immediately changed into a massive scary flying lion.As the game progresses, you find some tasks which are similar, but its fun to just do these in a more ridiculous way than you did it the last time!

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												Fed people in the diner. You can literally feed a cannibal "corpse" or "baby". 12/10.Seriously though. This game gives you a lot of options for how to solve problems, and lets you apply a certain degree of customization to it. My only complaint is that (so far?) you only unlock brothers to play as. Is Lily really the only sister of the family? I think little girls would like female characters to play as too. Still, you can give the guys dresses and wigs to wear, so if you really wish to express your feminine side, get creative!You can also spawn gigantic beasts that attack people. Or ride around everywhere on a pegasus.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
Youngsters addiction!Be careful what you do, this game actually is fun to play. You can mess around in your environment and ... well, just by adding adjectives or nouns you can change the game.Ohh, don't get too cocky though, you can get killed in this game too. And using the same words over and over again won't get you a high-score in the game. You can also create your own stuff. Well if you wish that is.It is a game in which the player can get creative, in a most verbose way, giving live to your own ideas to solve quests and riddles. And with each starite you get closer to the ultimate goal of the game.The game is captivating, because it has a lot of quite comedic capabilities. If you ever has a chance to lay your hands on this game for a low price, don't think twice, just get it - if you love creative games you should get it anyway, regardless of price!A clear vote for recommendation!

content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												It's casual.  And open world.  And it invokes creativity.  And it is even intelligent in certain aspects.  However, perhaps the main feature that makes this game really neat is because although it gives an ample selection of pre-created objects & NPCs in any given part of the game's world, you can create practically anything imaginable using your Notepad, and then add in-game "Adjectives" that describe the object and will alter its behavior.  To top it off, this amazing game comes complete with Steam Workshop support, so you can share your fun creations with others and utilize their content in your own gameplay.  Definately recommend you try it!

content:
Posted: November 20, 2013
												Scribblenauts Unlimted is the game you go to when you want to let your imagination run wild. You want a ridable fire-breathing huge Cthulu? You can have it. You want a diamond coat? You can have it.Anything you want, in this game, there's a 90% chance you can have it. And if the thing you want isn't in the game? Make it yourself or download something like it from the Steam Workshop! :DYou are Maxwell, and your sister, Lily, has been cursed by an evil old man and is turning into stone, and the only way to stop her from fully turning into stone is by going out around the world and doing good deeds for people to collect "Starites" to make everything better, and for her to stop turning into stone.With your magical notebook, you can create anything you want, your imagination can run wild in this game.The game also comes with Steam Achievements and Trading Cards, as well as Workshop support for the game, so getting new content is so easy, just by the click of a button!The replay value in the game is pretty large, considering you can do anything you want, and collecting all of the stariets will be quite a challenge, but rewarding in the end.The game can get pretty repetitive at times though, which is unfortunate, considering it shouldn't be repetitive at all, there's a lot of "I want this" quests, and it can get quite annoying after a while, doing the same quest for a person with a different name.I give this game an 8.9/10, it's a great game, but a few shortcomings stop it from being a perfect game.I still would recommend you to buy it, it's worth the asking price of £14.99.
