content:
Posted: August 13, 2013
												Scribblenauts is a lot of fun without going very deep. You can enjoy the entire world map and the main story without getting any object shards... little word-play puzzles based on how seperate objects interact. And this is what I did. I finished the whole game, unaware that I hadn't done everything I could.Then, when I noticed all those achievements I hadn't gotten, I opened the menu, looked at the "shards" and immediately became twice as entertained. That's right: I became twice as entertained once I'd _finished_ the game.A beauty queen is tired of being pretty. Make her a "lycanthropic beauty queen" and spawn a full moon, and you get a shard. That's what an object shard is. And it's amazing.I'm plowing through all those now, but suffice to say, this game is creative and fun and it makes me happy. Avoid the temptation to look any of the answers up; The puzzles are fairly simple and you'll get it on one or two tries, and there's nothing more gratifying than figuring out a solution like lycanthropic beauty queen.Buy.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Scribblenauts Unlimited is a brilliant concept. You're faced with a myriad of problems throughout the game and have to solve them by conjuring items from a magic notebook. The number of items you can conjure is impressive. Everything from the Kraken, to God, to microbes and dark matter can be summoned to solve challenges. You can spend ages figuring out the most ingenious way to solve a puzzle, and seeing your solution finally work is satisfying. Unfortunately, there's little incentive to solve puzzles this way when more obvious methods are just as effective. Some items cannot be summoned at all, even if they seem obvious (blood comes to mind). Nevertheless, Scribblenauts is a charming puzzler which can be fun for adults as well as the kids.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												- If you've played the previous Scribblenauts, would not recommend.- If you've never heard of Scribblenauts in your life and you like coming up with creative answers to things, go for it. My view's quite biased as I played the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of the original and ESPECIALLY Super Scribblenauts, big fan of the series, but was severely disappointed with Unlimited.A lot easier and boring than the previous Scribblenauts. 3/4s of the way through, still not having any fun, except for the odd randomness here and there.The answers are either really stupidly obvious or really stupidly not-obvious - and that's not in a funny way.I liked the old 'advanced' system, where you'd have to replay the levels with different answers every time. That encouraged more creative thinking.The hints are also a lot more blatant in Unlimited - "Try using a hat" or "He wants a place to sleep".But, the new object editor feature is pretty damn awesome. Made a cat-spawning afro, spawned hundreds of cats, didn't crash, 10/10. Though I kind of wish the old level maker was still in the game, that would've kept me more interested in the game if we could try other people's levels.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Scribblenauts Unlimited may seem like kids-only game but it is fun for kids of all ages ;). Fun is not as much in finding a solution to the puzzle (as most of them will be rather obvious) but rather finding the most wacky solution you can think of and make it work. Of course you can help the pirate by giving him more cannonballs to shoot out of his cannon, but why not try giving him tiny pink chickens and see what happens. The world around changes with your every action and creating one small innocent zombie may result in having a horde of undead-everything few minutes after.So let your imagination go wild!

												As my first Scribblenauts game, I was blown away at how open the player is to interact in EVERY SINGLE LEVEL. Your imagination is your only limitation to this game as you incorperate adjectives and nouns to complete challenges or riddles that the NPC's give you. I had a relaxing time with this game and could reccomend it to anybody.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Imagination, thy name is Scribblenauts Unlimited. Aside for another great story across many boards that challenge your ability to think of fun, creative or creepy solutions to problems big and small, this installment also includes the Object Editor, where you can take anything and make anything. A giant grandma with cars for arms that shoots out cats at clowns? Done. A hydra that has a dog head, a dragon head and an ant head that is colored like a sweater? Check. A purple angel that explodes when it comes in contact with cheese in a nuclear fireball? Bingo.I've had hours and hours of fun with this game and it never gets old. It's worth every penny

												Personal Rating: 8 of 10Great fun for the young and adult. Scribblenauts is a puzzle adventure games where you travel from one map to another and help the characters residing in the area by creating and manipulating objects! You can create from animals to robots to even becoming Zeus yourself. The game offers unlimited space for your imagination and creativity. Play with your family and kids as this seems to be a great platform for learning as well. However, you can only create objects that are not copyrighted and the objects comes in limited visuals; but this can be overcome by downloading objects designed by other players or create your own in the editor.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2013
												I spent a little over 10 hours in this game doing every level and every side quest. I did not do the mini-puzzles in the book but I did every level.I enjoyed the game quite a bit, but almost the entire game was too easy and the puzzles were funny but not hard.The basic idea is that you can use a book to spell out any item or change a description of an item to solve puzzles. You can be very creative and specific or you can be simple and generic.... both will generally solve the puzzles.There was no combat missions, or create a situation level... so after I played every level, I decided to goof around and make "massive epic mega ultra portal" and have giant monsters do battle, but quickly found that playing outside of puzzles isn't as fun as i wanted.Cool game, worth it but only for the casual who is creative.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												Scribblenauts is such a great idea for a game. Choose the items you want to create to solve the puzzle. This game can create practically anything. Sure, some words that are similar end up looking the same, but it seems like the game's dictionary is huge. When I find myself find certain words too often, I'll try to stop using it because I want to make different items appear.You can choose to pass every level or cause destruction. This game has replayable because you can try solving the same puzzle with different words. The possibilities are nearly endless it seems. And, you can change your character which is awesome. There are no voice-overs, but who needs that when you have the nouns of the English language at your fingertips.If you love puzzle adventure games like I do, buy this game!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												Sbcribblenauts is a very unique type of game. You are given the power to create anything, and i mean anything. Even if it isn't programmed into the game, chances aer someone on steam has made it and uploaded it. If not, you can create it yourself. The visuals are cartoony, like a drawing, and the sound is nice and cheerful. The story consists of you helping multiple people to make them happy. It dose get boring after a while, but it's always fun to mess around and see what kind of crazy situation you can get yourself into. 8/10

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												Scribblenauts Unlimited is a very impressive game. The whole point of the game is to simply conjure any item you want (within reason) at any time. The Scribblenauts series consists of a range of small puzzles that require you to use whatever items you want to complete your objective, earning a star in the process. Scribblenauts Unlimited differs from the previous game in the series by having a small free-roam element that steps away from simply clicking on the unlocked level you want to do, but rather you find puzzles through exploration. Another new feature is the object creation, where players may create their own items that they can share online. I recommend this game for puzzle fans with imagination, people who think outside 'the box' and idiots who want to see Deadpool fight an army of vampires while riding Alduin.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
 Positive + Simplistic and cute art style+ Big variety in the amount of objects and creations you can generate, sometimes leading to comedic outcomes+ Good enough length for what the gameplay has to offer (around 4 ½ hours for the main game, add another 2-3 hours if you want to do everything the game offers). Negative - Gameplay is overall too simple (though the game is targeted at a younger audience, so this is intentional). Verdict “A very fun and creative package, Scribblenauts Unlimited gives the user an environment with (almost) complete free reign to design solutions to many various problems. Think word association with added charm.” 7.5/10 TJBs

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												Scribblenauts Unlimited is your average scribblenauts game. Scribblenauts, as you may already know, started out as a series of Nintendo DS games, Like Scribblenauts and Super Scribblenauts.Now, Don't look away from this game. This game, is, in MY opinion, is the best game in the entire series. Now, lets start with the plot. One time, long ago, there were two young adventurers, Grandma Julie, and Grandpa Edgar. Now, these two often challenged eachother as they explored all over the world. But, it always seemed Julie beat Edgar to the treasure. One day, Julie, Who once again, Beats Edgar to a lost pyramid, Found an engagement ring! Awww... The two retired to start a family. And wanna guess how many kids they had? FORTY FREAKING TWO. Anyways. They had two special  children, named Maxwell and Lily. They gave them Two amazing gifts. One of them was a magic globe, that allowed them to go anywhere they pleased. The second, was the greatest notebook ever found-- It was able to create anything you wrote into it. "Like a flying rainbow laser-eyed dolphin?" ... Yes .... Anyways, They're parents, (Yeah, Remeber them?) Thought that giving them these gifts will turn them into spoiled brats. So they sent them off, to face the challenges of the outside world. On they way to the city, they ran into an old man, who said he was famished. So Maxwell, ignoring common sense and not using the notebook for good, Gave the old man something to eat, Which was an apple. No. Not any regular apple, A rotten one! The old man spat out the part of the apple he ate, and somehow places a curse on Lily that is turning her to stone! Maxwell creates a red wagon, and hurrys off to Edwin's Farm. Edwin, who is one of maxwell's brothers, is a farmer. Edwin seemed pretty upset with Maxwell and what he did to the peasant. So, in order to remove the curse, Maxwell needs to collect Starites, by making people happy and using the notebook for good. DANG! That was a pretty dang long plot summary. Anyways, onto the next segment of this review. GRAPHICS! This game. Oh my gosh, THIS GAME. Has some of the best graphics I have ever seen! Not only to we get to learn Maxwell's Backstory, But we learn in in HD Graphics! Next up, MUSIC!My gosh, they went all out with the soundtrack on this one. It sounds aboslutely wonderful! Its just a joy to listen to. GAMEPLAY! Now, heres the thing that is just so cool about scribblenauts. You can CREATE anything you write down! And you use this to your advantage to solve puzzles! DOWNSIDE! Well, the real downside is, that it seems that the puzzles have been... A bit.. Simplifed... And thats what kind of drags about this game. The puzzles are either really easy, which is about 45% of them, Medium, about the same, 45%, and Hard? About 10%. So, The games difficulty is so out of place, like, sometimes, theres an easy level with ONE single hard puzzle in it. That is the downside to this game. But, Sence it IS a scribblenauts game, You know, YOU KNOW It has to be good. My rating? 9.3 out of 10. Scribblenauts Unlimited, Is alot better than the ones on DS, but sometimes the difficulty gets in the way. But I still recommend you give it a go.

												I have completed this game and have gone through all the missions and done all the achievements, and I can tell you it's not as fun as I expected. content:
Posted: January 15
												If you're looking for a game review than you came to the wrong place, now if you wanted a delicious pancake recipe...Ingredients + EquipmentYou’ll need a mixing bowl, a wire whisk, a spatula and a non-stick griddle or skillet. An electric griddle works wonders too, if you make a lot of pancakes at your house. The ingredients you’ll need are:1 ¼ cup milk  2 eggs 2 tablespoons vegetable oil 2 cups all-purpose flour 2 tablespoons sugar 3 teaspoons baking powder ¼ teaspoon saltThe BatterPancakes aren’t complicated, so the batter is everything! For best results, mix that bowl of batter up right before it’s going to hit the griddle.The wet ingredients come together first. Beat the milk, eggs and vegetable oil in a mixing bowl with a wire whisk.The dry ingredients—flour, baking powder, sugar and salt—are then stirred into the wet mixture. Baking powder is what makes the pancakes fluffy, while the sugar helps the exterior caramelize just enough. And a dash of our friend salt enhances the flavor.Gently mix everything together until it’s combined, but still lumpy. It’ll only take about 10-15 seconds to get to that liquidy-lumpy state. If you over-mix the batter, you’re going to be chowing down on a very tough, rubbery pancake because the gluten molecules start having a party. If you under-mix, you might end up with a mouthful of flour.The CookingBrush a non-stick griddle or skillet with vegetable oil, clarified butter or cooking spray before heating. You don’t need too much with a nonstick pan. (You may be tempted to use regular butter, but it tends to burn easily. Save the butter for the breakfast table.)Heat the griddle over medium-high heat. To determine when the griddle is ready for pancake action, run your hand under the faucet and carefully flick just a tiny bit of water onto the surface of the pan. The water droplets will bead up and sizzle when it’s ready.Pour ¼ cup of batter onto the hot griddle and cook 1-2 minutes or until the bubbles on the surface have finished popping and the pancake is dry around the edges.Now it’s time to flip. Using a spatula, gently turn the pancake over and cook on the other side until golden brown.Serve warmFluffy PancakesPrint Recipe  (0)    0 View Full RecipeIngredientsStepsHow to Keep Pancakes HotIf you’re cooking for a crowd, turn the oven to 325°F and put your finished pancakes on a baking sheet as they come off the griddle. That way they all stay hot until you are ready to eat.How to Store Leftover Pancakes in the FreezerStack cooled pancakes between a sheet of waxed paper or parchment. Wrap the stack in foil and freeze. To reheat, preheat the oven to 400°F. Unwrap frozen pancakes and remove from waxed paper. Heat pancakes in a single layer on an ungreased cookie sheet for 5 to 7 minutes or until heated through.How to Store Leftover BatterStoring leftover batter is one of those things one could technically do, but should one? Nah, one really shouldn’t.The baking powder loses its oomph very quickly and the gluten molecules have a field day of chewiness when they are allowed to sit around. Rather than storing leftover batter, we recommend making just the right amount of batter for your breakfast or cooking up the whole batch and storing leftover pancakes in the freezer as directed above.Back To TopTwists on PancakesPancakes are meant to be twisted! There are so many ways you can upgrade your pancakes, from batter mix-ins to mid-griddle additions to final toppings.Batter mix-ins might include pureed pumpkin with pumpkin pie spice, lemon zest and ricotta cheese or even mashed bananas. Our Gingerbread Pancakes are perfect for the holidays. Buttermilk is a common substitute for milk in pancakes too, as the acidity provides extra volume, browning and flavor. Adding additional (or different) wet ingredients may mean you need to adjust your dry ingredients accordingly, so unless you’re simply shaking a bit of cinnamon into your batter, you’ll want to follow a recipe to make sure your flavored pancakes turn out perfectly.Mid-griddle additions would include those tasty bits that you’ll want to place on your hot cakes before you flip them—things like whole berries, chocolate chips, crunchy granola or little pieces of bacon. Adding these types of things to the individual pancakes rather than the batter helps them stay evenly distributed and keeps them from burning. You can use the same Fluffy Pancake recipe outlined above and easily personalize it with whatever you like without changing the batter.Topping options are pretty much unlimited when it comes to pancakes, and also don’t require any new recipe. Obviously butter and maple syrup are classic pancake pairings for a reason—there is no substitute for a hefty drizzle of real maple syrup. But it’s also wonderful to think outside the syrup container and try topping your pancakes with jam, caramel, nuts, fruit, whipped cream, sprinkles and more!8 Easy Twists on Pancakes Gingerbread PancakesGingerbread Pancakes Blueberry Sour Cream PancakesBl

content:
Posted: February 24, 2013
												I never really did like Scribblenauts on the Nintendo DS, but it was a great concept nevertheless. Imagine that you can write down anything - ANYTHING - in your notepad and it appears as an (animated) object. That's... that's just awesome, don't you agree ? All you need is a bit of imagination and you create the wildest things.Still, I was a bit sceptic when I purchased and played Scribblenauts Unlimited because: 1) I thought it would be a simple port, and 2) it wouldn't be any fun for me now (if it wasn't already back then, right ?). I'm so glad I was wrong - once again.Scribblenauts is an amazing port, with beautiful art that looks extremely detailed in 2560x1440. The overview map is the one thing that looks kinda low res. Other than that; great stuff. And there are so many (parts of) stars to collect that you'll never run out of things to do (ok, maybe not, but still...). This game has character !Another thing that took some time to get used to, though, was the fact that you have to switch between mouse and keyboard frequently. It's nothing major, but it's a bit clumsy.Scribblenauts should be in anyone's collection, especially considering the price.[Rating: 77/100]

Posted: November 26, 2013
												A polished and full-featured offering to the Scribblenauts series. Being on PC and having access to things like the keyboard and the Steam Workshop greatly improve the game. It is somewhat annoying to have to figure out what the game wants you to say, as its understanding of words can be limited at time. For instance, one puzzle needs you to evaluate a piece of art and typing "art expert" doesn't work, but "expert" by itself does. A mechanic can't repair a robot because a mechanic repairs cars, but a scientist can because science. Little things like that. Luckily those issues aren't usually a huge barrier to progress.

												When this game first came out it was original and different and I remember enjoying the original Scribblenauts on my Nintendo DS, but playing it now the puzzles feel dull and takes an excruciatingly low amount of effort to solve a problem. I can't help but feel this game is very childish and is marketed towards younger audiences with everything being resolved by common sense. "Hey I need to get smarter do something" *Adds smart adjective to the character* "Hey I'm smart now you did it" HOORAY -_- I really can't help but feel dissapointed by this game.

Posted: November 30, 2015
I love sandbox games, and this brought a whole new meaning to that genre to meI may be a little late to discover this game, but all these things still apply today. OverviewVenture into a wide-open world where the most powerful tool is your imagination. Help Maxwell solve robust puzzles in seamless, free-roaming levels by summoning any object you can think of. Create your own original objects, assign unique properties, and share them with friends online using Steam Workshop – to be used in game or further modified as you like! Points of interestThe amount of things you can create and do in this game is staggering, plus it's got steam workshop!If it exists, you can probably type it!Animate your creations with adjectives, provides for even more possibilities.The puzzles are fun and can be completed in many different ways, not just one.Around 13 or 14 hours of gameplay to complete the storyEasy to 100% achievments-Some puzzles may be difficult for kids, but there is always guides to help with that.-Controls can be a little frustrating if you use your mouse to move, and clicking on things can be challenging, but WASD is a welcome alternativeSummaryA charming game full of possibilities. Recommended for all ages: great for the kids or for you to play in your spare time! 9/10

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												When the astoundingly ambitious Scribblenauts was originally released for the Nintendo DS I completely loved it.  You were tasked with solving a simple puzzle – get a starite (the game’s star-shaped macguffin), and to do so you could conjure up just about any item you could think of, from the commonplace like cars and ladders, to more outside-the-box things like arsonists and marimbas.  I was always surprised such an excellent game was made by 5th Cell, a game company that was, up to that point, a veritable mediocrity factory.  Was 5th Cell secretly a team of amazing game designers?Scribblenauts Unlimited answers this question with a resounding “No.”Unlimited introduces some new features that should make this game a hit – like an item editor that allows you to create your own stuff.  And, as much as I appreciate a game that allows me to make a bazooka that shoots newborn infants, the new mission-style of the game itself is what ruins it.  Doing a simple task like “get a starite” was rewarding because the solution was open to your imagination.  There was any number of solutions you could use and solving a level made you feel smart and accomplished.  When someone gives you a mission in Unlimited by saying “Boy, I’m hungry.” I don’t care if you say pizza, artichokes, or quinoa, thinking of a kind of food will never feel like an accomplishment.  Also, people who give their missions out to you exist in such a cramped space, sometimes you accidentally solve other peoples’ missions without intending to.

content:
Posted: March 19
												 you're looking for a game review you've come to the wrong place. But if youre looking for a fantastic ravioli recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients- To Make the Dough375 grams (3 cups) plain flour1/2 teaspoon salt2 eggs1/4 cup (50 ml / 3½ tablespoons) olive oil1/2 cup (120 ml / 8 tablespoons) waterExtra flour for dusting - To Make Cheese Filling15 ounces (425 grams) container Ricotta cheese5 ounces (142 g/about 1/2 cup plus 2 tablespoons) "3 Cheese Italian Blend" (Parmesan, Romano & Asiago)Note: grate these cheeses yourself and create your own custom blend.1/2 cup cheddar cheese2 eggs, lightly beaten1/2 teaspoon salt1/2 teaspoon pepper- ExtrasYour favorite sauce for the ravioli (i.e. marinara/ marijuana)Parmesan cheeseBasilFried vegetablesShrimpFish slicesChicken pieces Make the Ravioli filling.- In a small mixing bowl, add the ricotta and mash with a fork.- Add in the 3-cheese blend, Cheddar cheese, eggs, salt, and pepper.- Mix all ingredients thoroughly until you have a smooth, paste-like consistency.- Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and place it in the refrigerator for about 30 minutes. Make the Ravioli dough.- Crack eggs into a large mixing bowl and beat them with a fork. Add water, oil, and salt. Mix.- Add 1 cup flour to the bowl. Use a fork to mix the flour with the eggs, water, oil, and salt. Repeat with the rest of the flour. Mix until a smooth dough is formed.- Clear and clean off a large work surface and dust it with flour. This is where you are going to roll out your dough.- Take the dough out of the mixing bowl, shape it into a ball, and place it on your work surface. Knead for at least 10 minutes or until it becomes elastic.- Dust a rolling pin with flour to prevent the dough from sticking. Roll out the dough until it is about 1/8 inch (1/3 cm) thick, or about the thickness of 2 stacked quarters.- With a cookie cutter or upside-down water glass, cut out circles in the dough (will make about 15-20 dough circles).- Ball up the unused dough and either roll it out and make a couple more raviolis, or wrap it and put in the freezer for another time. Dough can keep for weeks when frozen. Just make sure to wrap well so that it doesn’t suffer from freezer burn or absorb freezer odor. Fill the Ravioli shells.- Take the ravioli filling out of the refrigerator and place a tablespoon of it in middle of a dough.- Fill a small bowl with water, dip your fingers in, and moisten around the outer edge of the dough circle.- Fold the dough in half over the filling, making a half-moon shape. Be sure all the filling stays inside. Pinch the edges together and then seal the edges of the ravioli with a fork. Make sure to press firmly and go all the way around. This will add a “homemade” touch as well.- Repeat this process for all your dough circles.- Dust the finished ravioli with flour to keep them from sticking together. Form the Shells and Fill Using a Ravioli maker.- Roll the dough into two sheets- Place one sheet on the ravioli maker, and form the filling cups.- Fill with the ravioli mixture.- Lay the second sheet of dough on top, and roll it out. This will seal in the filling.- Remove and separate the finished raviolis.Cook the Ravioli.- Fill a large pot with water and bring to a boil.- Place the ravioli in boiling water for 5-6 minutes, or until they float. You can also test for doneness by nibbling on the edges to test.- If you don't want to make all the ravioli at one time, you can freeze the rest - Take ravioli out of boiling water with large slotted spoon and place on warmed platesServe it up.Top with your favorite sauce, grate some fresh cheese over it, and enjoy!

content:
Posted: February 8
More Bells and Whistles with Less Challenging PuzzlesLike Lego, I am more impressed by its predecessors(the originals) than the later editionsWAY back when I remember my friend showed me Scribblenauts, I was determined to achieve all stars/most creative methods on all levels. I borrowed her game and played it religiously.Less is more?This edition has a coreherent world, an editor to create your own customized items among other functions. Yet, I feel that because all the puzzles are scenario-specific to fit into the world, the possibilities become limited. Trust me, I have summoned a Gentlemanly Cthuhlu to scare a pegasus drawing a piece of rope to move a car...or an oil rig to crush a bad guy...so I have tried my best to solve problems impractically. In the end, something is still kind of lacking...Some of my overall positve experienceEasy to learn and navigate, but the menu can be a bit cumbersomeCharacters and art is still bright and quirky as everCreate and use your own character instead of eg.MaxwellCute but confined scenariosStill a unique puzzle gameConsAs i have mentioned, more restrictive than is predecessorThe user base creation becomes mostly flooded with fanart of games and memes Personally I was hoping to see a game that encourages creative problem solving and ridiculous thinking rather than being  limited by a series of very situational scenariosConclusion:Take a wee bit of my money or none at all: I am reluctantly giving this a not recommended rating because I have seen better release from the Scribblenauts series. It is still a fun game but it has definitely fallen short. As a result, it's not a must have. Feel free to purchase this though, as it can still be entertaining.

content:
Posted: March 15
												This series used to be good, and it still is in a way.  But after the adjective system was added, the challenge, and the value of most of the game, was lost.  What used to be a game that tested your ability in word association has now turned into a game about making up nonsensical items.  The ways you can solve puzzles now are so easy; you could complete a majority of the game using nothing but sticks.  Here are a few examples:"Make an item that will put out this fire." CRYING STICK"Prepare a steak for this customer" COOKING STICK"Make something for this art museum" BEAUTIFUL MODERN STICK"Give Santa something he likes, but doesn't already have" MERRY STICK"Scare away the Vampire" HOLY STICK"Make this date more romantic" ROMANTIC STI- actually, don't use that one.Point is, the game has been simplified by this mechanic, and it doesn't reward you in any way for being logical or creative.  Kinda sad, because if they did, you would have a clear, straight upgrade of a game from the first Scribblenauts.  The workshop is flooded with poor remakes of copyrighted characters; something that was purposely left out in the original games.  Its a shame I can't recommend this, because the amount of work put into the engine and content would definitely be worth the $20 price tag if the single player wasn't so absurdly easy.  The most enjoyable part of this game is derping around like its a sandbox game.  If that sounds like something you would get a kick out of, by all means buy this.  Just know that the single player ain't worth♥♥♥♥♥♥PS: This game has a sequel with DC Comic characters in it.  Same kind of game play, and the addition of DC characters doesn't do much for the game itself.  About the only thing that it does is add visual assets to the workshop mods.  So... you're not really missing much in that one either :v  I guess go for it if you are a fan of derping and comic book hero's?

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												I recommend this game for children that already know or are learning how to read and write. Do I recommend this game to adults? No.This game is simply not challenging enough for an adult to play. The starite sequences are easy to complete, and the shard hints are easy to figure out. When it comes down to it, the most gameplay you'll be engaging in is pressing "Enter" and typing. True, you can do some goofy things like making people blind and making animals fly, turn colors, or force school children to eat cats, but when that is said and done, the game doesn't get much more entertaining.The achievements are rather easy to unlock aswell. All of the shards are available to unlock without any prerequisites, and the starites are achieved through normal gameplay. The most backtrackingI had to do was resetting a level maybe three times. It's nearly impossible to fail at this game unless you accidentally get Maxwell killed. There are no timed levels and the game eventually tells you what to spawn if you take too long to complete a task during a starite mission. My five year old loved this game. He enjoyed the themed levels, the ability to spawn almost anything, and how he could interact with almost all of the objects. We would often play together and the game motivated him to learn how to spell.  He would ask me how to spell certain words and I believe the game made learning a little bit more enjoyable for him. He played this game for a long time before moving on to Scribblenauts: Unmasked.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2013
												Scribblenauts is finally available on PC (and now finally available in Europe as well!)  It's a fun little game that has you solve word puzzles by typing in words to create just about anything you could want.  Objects can be modified with a wide variety of adjectives and you can ever create your own objects with custom scripting.  If something isn't in the game already you can easily go find it on the Steam Workshop or create it yourself.To the game itself, it is very fun.  Puzzles can be solved in a wide variety of different ways, giving you room to be creative.  A few of the puzzles are very obtuse which is an annoyance when you run into them, but it's not game breaking.I'm not sure what else there is to say.  Go buy this game!

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												Scribblenouts Unlimited is one of the most fun casual puzzle games I have ever played. Pretty much all puzzles are very easy (if you know the language well enough) which usually makes for a horrible and boring game, but that's not the case with this one. It's because difficulty is not the mane goal of this theme, it's creativity. In this game puzzles are completed by writing nouns to create new objects or adding adjectives to existing objects. Once you get the gang of the mechanics of the game it becomes ridiculously fun. My personal highlight of the game was the moment when I had to retrieve a ball from an old dudes yard without him noticing aaaaaaaand I just added the adjective "blind" to him. I felt so evil once it worked.Get it you dummy!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2013
												Have you seen a Flying Rideable Hipster Manical Supersonic Supercharged Sparkling Golden Toaster Oven!? Well I have. You can too if you get this game of PURE FUN.Don't let the cartoony style fool you into thinking this is a game for kids, this is easily one of the most f*cked up games I've ever played to date. In just 20 minutes of play I've helped a chef at his restaurant cook up random things that his customers wanted, one guy wanted pizza so I gave the chef human body parts for his pizza ingredients that made a lovely human pizza afterwards, the dude totally ate the whole thing without a clue, ha ha dummy. The next person wanted a motorcycle... okay, wrong place n' all but whatever I'll just throw some part together and make a bike for you no problem, EXCEPT! once the kickin' rad bike was done the chef decided to take it for himself and drove off with it leaving a crying customer for me to deal. Wasn't my restaurant though so not my problem, I then bailed to some school.First thing I noticed here was this bully forcing some nerd into a locker, I helped this nerd by summoning Mutha Fu**in' NITO, yes NITO from Dark Souls, who then bullied the crap out of this bully, after soaking in all this glorious irony I then moved onto the cafeteria to help with school lunch, this was a no brainer for me, I fed them a ♥♥♥♥♥ (not that kind :/), unfortunately the kids all died from eating it, not sure why when China eats cats n' stuff, but whatever it didn't matter at that point because I already got my star. I then just flew off on a flying pregnant baby going at supersonic speeds with Solaire from Dark Souls where we praised the Sun for the rest of that play session. This all in just 20 minutes.Seriously get this game, you should play this now. Never mind the fact that little Maxwell is an idiot that almost got his sister killed, all that matters is with this Notebook YOU ARE AN ALL POWERFUL GOD AND SHOULD GIVE ZERO F*CKS.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2013
												Scribblenauts Unlimited is pretty damn fun. Whether you're getting this for yourself, your grandma or your young nephew, this game is great. It's really kid friendly and great for all ages. It definitely has it's drawbacks, but I'd say this game is on the positive side.Scribblenauts is a game where you can create objects by simply typing in their name and they will poof into existence. Now this is limited to objects that have already been created in the engine and as hard as much as you may want to summon some naked gurls, you can't make anything lewd which is fine honestly.The purpose of the game is to collect stars, kind of like Mario 64 and other games, to save your sister or whatever. To get stars you summon objects and things to solve problems. This can be done with lots of different items which you will need to be somewhat creative with, but at the same time you can always just summoner a hover tank and make yourself fly to do most things.Overall the game is solid and just simple fun. Worth around 15 to 25 bucks based on how you value your time.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												Great game!!! Tons of interesting, unique, and colorful levels. The story is good. You run around helping people for starites(I won't say why because spoilers!!). You really have to be creative with this game. This can get repetitive though. The graphics are great. The HD added with the color is beautiful and since it is 2D it should be easy for all computers. As for content there's lots to do. Even when your done the game you still have tons to do as anything you right will appear. How they put all this in? No clue! When you think you have seen it all there's more. It has something called object editor  . With this you can make anything you want (It is not to complicated either), you can then post your creation on steam workshop. With Steam Workshop you can see and use other peoples creations, this adds a new level to the game. Overall its a fun game for a casual gamer but if you were expecting it to be all sirius and precis, you came to the wrong place. Overall I give the game 8.3/10

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												If you have played Scribblenauts on NDS or IOS and are hoping this game is exactally the same you are sadly wrong. This game is fun but when it comes to creating things out of words it cant be compared to the NDS or IOS port. Simply because it doesnt recognize half the words you put together. For example in the first city there is gaffiti drawn on the wall and you have to get rid of it, So you may be thinking lets get creative with the words so you type Paint Eraser, or Paint Thinner and the game asks you did you mean this, and it gives you 5 pages of words you possibly dont know to replace the words you typed. Its like they took the worst part of gooogle search from the year 2005 by saying did you mean this, and made it into a game.The game is really fun once you get past the flaw of being creative with words and you can even make your own creations and replace other creations with your own in a level such as a ant with your own design by clicking on it and recreating it. But with the 1 flaw thats holding it back it feels like its not the same scribblenauts from the NDS or IOS and was simply made poorly as if the game was made by a different company.The game is a defininate buy but if your a fan of the Original games on NDS or IOS then prepare for extreme ammounts of being angry because the game wont let you make paint thinner for paint but somehow an eraser can get rid of the paint which has no creativity at all when you are trying to get crazy creative with word creations.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												Some puzzles are very specific with their solutions, which makes the ability to "create anything" a little daunting. These puzzles are far and few between but frustrating when trying to get 100%. Most of the puzzles were a breeze, so the difficulty spikes were never really in a middle ground, either super easy (most of them) or very specific (difficult).Good for kids and adults alike... but more for kids I'm sure.

Posted: January 29, 2014
												An adult version of this would be SOOO much more fun. I cannot even begin to tell you the amount of things you can do if this was an adult version. But it is a PG version and limited words to choose. A lot of puzzles of certain limited answers when clearly there are more than those few. So it becomes a frustrating exp of choosing and typing and trying until you get stuck and go online and look for it. After a few hours, it becomes repetitive. Suitable for young children but I doubt anyone older than 15 is going to find it fun.

												Some puzzles are very specific with their solutions, which makes the ability to "create anything" a little daunting. content:
Posted: January 26, 2016



YouTube™ Video: Steam Cleaning - Scribblenauts Unlimited 

			Views: 3		

			A magic notebook that creates anything that you write into it can lead to a lot of trouble and a lot of good. To save your sister you must travel the world solving problems to make people happy.		

A magic notebook that creates anything that you write into it can lead to a lot of trouble and a lot of good.  To save your sister you must travel the world solving problems to make people happy.The majority of the puzzles can be solved with a small set of words but the real fun is thinking up creative ways to solve problems.  While aimed for younger players this game is still enjoyable for all ages.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												It's really fun once you play it. You can make anything appear, except for: real life copyrighted items, vulgar items, and other inappropriate items. If you REALLY want to make those objects, you'll have to create them yourself, using the Item Editor. There is a main story to it and if you actually try to complete it, you can unlock more places to go to. You have the notebook to use for every part in the story. Creating items is the key to this game with adjectives and nouns. I would DEFINITELY reccommend this game for anyone with a creative mind. The possibilities are endless. Also, you can edit yourself however you want to, except that you can't change the torso on Maxwell's body in the Avatar Editor. Sorry, but that star on his chest will stay there.

												Kind of fun at first. But way too simple for an adult. The thing that makes this game fun is trying to find silly ways to solve problems. content:
Posted: July 23, 2013
												Don't expect the same gameplay as the first two games on DS. While Unlimited is just as charming as the originals, the gameplay is relegated to simply helping other characters perform actions. You're basically "Helper Scribblenaut." The solution to most puzzles is pretty linear and you wind up not feeling nearly as creative as in the previous titles. But if you don't have a DS, and this is your only way to experience Scribblenauts, check it out!

number of helpful: 22 of 47 people (47%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												I cannot recommend this game. The game consists of various locations populated by people (or animals, or other objects) that have a problem to be solved. These "problems" or "puzzles" are usually incredible simple, like "This guy is hungry. Give him something to solve his hunger" or "this girl wants something to wear to a party", or "this ghost wants to see his reflection", or "this elephant wants to be a painter. Give him something a painter would have", or "this jockey needs something to ride for the race". You "solve" the puzzles by using your notebook to create an item for the person in question: "dinner", "dress", "mirror", "palette", "horse". You can be creative in your solutions ("pink polka dot flying horse"), but other than self-amusement, there's no incentive not to go with the first obvious answer the pops in your head. Young children may get a kick out of this game, but personally I thought the game was pretty boring.

Posted: December 14, 2013
												This is a really charming game, and the idea behind it is fantastic. The amount of words in the dictionary is really impressive, and you can solve puzzles pretty much any ridiculous way you want. But if you're looking for a good brain workout, look elsewhere. This is by no means a brain-teaser. I'm really confused as to what audience this game was intended for. It's so simplistic that a 6 year old could easily figure out all the puzzles, but there are words and references that only an adult would get. If it was meant to be played by parents and children together (which would make sense), it's certainly not marketed that way. The unfortunate truth is that this game gets boring incredibly fast. You can solve puzzles in very creative ways, but there is no incentive to try because the game rewards you exactly the same way no matter what you do. You could create a giant burning zombie made of bacon to melt an iceberg in your way, but using a flamethrower will net you exactly the same result, so eventually the appeal of using your imagination wears off and you'll settle for the easy solution just to push through faster. Even playing with friends or being inebriated (which usually make anything awesome) only extends the fun for so long. If you're still curious and want to try it, at least wait for a sale, because $19.99 is just way too much of an asking price.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												The game is cute and the dictionary is a novelty you won't find in any other series, unfortunately the game's selling point is also kind of its downfall since it makes all the puzzles incredibly easy. There's no penalty for using the same words over and over and the game doesn't really reward cleverness, you can solve pretty much everything with adjectives or the same obvious solutions. A game with limitless potential for creativity isn't worth much when it offers no incentive to actually be creative beyond self-amusement. The controls are also pretty bad, you'll find yourself repeatedly accidentally opening menus and pausing the game when you try to attack things, although this game is very light on reflexive action as it is.. It's an alright sandbox if you get it in a sale, though if you've played any of the other Scribblemans games then you've already seen everything it has to offer.

												Yes, it's cute, and the potential to solve the puzzles in any way -at all- that you want is nice. But it is, for all that, rather a short game. I completed all the achievements the game had, as well as the game itself in far, far less than a day. It also falls over when you consider that many of the puzzles in the game can be solved in the same few ways. Work out one or two of the solutions that just repeatedly work and you can blast through the game extremely quickly. This leaves mopping up the collections to become a rather tedious task. The novelty wears off on Scribblenauts pretty quickly. It's fun at first, but that soon wears off, leaving you with an adorable game that's far too easy. I think this might be challenging for a small child. If you have a small child, give it to them to play, perhaps play it with them. Or just play it while you're too drunk to think clearly. This would be an amazing game to play while drunk.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												If you're looking for a creative/sandbox-ey type game to get into (think: Garry's Mod, Minecraft), look elsewhere. The puzzles in this game are all pretty much mind-numbingly obvious, and being creative is actually *discouraged* because the game engine won't accept or recognize most really creative solutions - so this often leaves you solving the puzzle with the first, most blatantly obvious thing that came to your mind.With this, I believe Scribblenauts Unlimited is a great game for the kiddies, considering its easy puzzles and the insane amount of objects you can spawn (they really did think of everything). I could see this being a great for the fam-fam if everyone sat down in front of the tele and played the Wii U port together.However, I'll have to give this a negative review because while the game and its description would like you to believe the limit is your imagination, it's really not.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Initially, Scribblenauts Unlimited leaves a favorable impression and gives the player a cool ability to generate almost anything out of thin air simply by typing the name of the desired object, as well as augment existing objects, by adding adjectives. Furthermore, generated objects believably interact with each other and the rest of the world, which allows for some creative problem solving. However, an initially cool concept soon turns into a tedious grind of giving hundreds of NPCs ordinary commonplace items level after level, and many of the references required to generate the right item would likely stump children young enough to enjoy what is essentially a word game. While the game offers quirky graphics and cool mechanics, I think reading a dictionary would be more fun and useful in the end.

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												In Scribblenauts you have to find solutions for problems by creating or altering objects/persons with your magic notebook. The amount of objects and adjectives available is enormous, but unfortunately the puzzles are lacking. In fact they are not even worth being called puzzles. Someone wants to chop down a tree? Give him an axe. Someone wants to fly? Give him wings. Someone wants a gift for his girlfriend? Give him flowers. And that's it. Of course you can use weird solutions, like giving the guy with the tree problem a 'huge pink funny demonic chainsaw', but the fun in doing things like these wears of pretty quickly. Especially since it doesn't change the outcome, the guy still chops down the tree just like he would with an axe. Often your weird creations aren't even used and standard objects are created instead. If you give a girl who wants to dress up nicely a pink miniskirt for example she'll just put on some default clothes instead of the object you created.The game can be fun for a few hours if you just mess around, but it gets boring pretty quickly. It is certainly a nice game for little children (age 5-10) though. So no recommendation for adults from me, but recommended for children.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												I've been meaning to play Scribblenauts for a long while, I wanted to see how good it was at realising what I had it mind.I've got to say the object creation and interaction definitely worked.However, in my opinion, Scribblenauts fails to be an actual game, it's just a tool to play with. I thought I would have to figure out puzzles by combining elements and unlocking stuff progressively. Sadly, that's not the case, almost all "challenges" simply ask you to create one single object, most of the time obvious. When you're asked to "write someone to help spy on the bandits", well the answer is obvious, a spy will do. Yes of course you can try more wild choices, and most of the time they will work. However, since everything has to be solved by inputting one single item, even the sandbox aspect is limited. Your word works or doesn't. It's in the game's list of possible answers or it's not. That's it. And there is only so many times I can get amused by giving overpowered or stupid items (especially since, if you go too wild, you risk destroying an important item and having to redo some stuff again).Dashed hopes... :/

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												I'm really surprised by how much I've come to hate this game. It is such a load of closed minded, sexist, anti-scientific, moralising rubbish. Many of the restrictions are merely reflections of the rating system in place for games so the devs aren't really to blame but when you put it in this context they become so incredibly infuriating. So for example, it is perfectly fine to spawn a flame-thrower and burning everyone alive. One the other hand woe betide you if you try to spawn anything relating to sex, drugs or alcohol because none of those words are in Scribbenauts' vocabulary. I get that this is a children's game but then why can we spawn flame throwers? Why is violence so often featured in the puzzles, often unavoidably? Why does one level feature torture? Why can we spawn iron-maidens if we feel like it? It is garbage. Moralising garbage that shoves a twisted morality down the player's throat where torture and violence are a-okay and sex and alcohol are the works of the devil.Other things are clearly in place just to reduce controversy so you can spawn old religious figures that not many people take seriously any more like Thor and Zeus but not Jesus, and Mohammed is right out. Mind you so are most of the historical figures I've wanted to spawn so far. Someone was clearly in the grip of internalised capitalist oppression so I tried to spawn Marx to talk some sense into them, I didn't seriously expect this to work but I did expect to be able to spawn Marx but no. I gave up and spawned a Lemon when that was the suggestion when I tried Lenin.On another occasion a scientist wanted someone to talk to so I tried to spawn Aristotle, this worked but it seems the game doesn't consider Aristotle to be a scientist so the scientist refused to talk to him. Einstein of course worked but it felt like such a hollow victory to resort to the bloody obvious. And the game forces you to resort to the bloody obvious so often. Thinking outside the box is so often met with no reaction at all from the game. Sometimes the box you're meant to be thinking inside is bloody stupidly defined as well. One of the hints was to solve the problem of needing to melt a block of ice to thaw out a prehistoric man "with science". I tried heating the ice in various ways. The ice melted but level was failed. I tried ordering the ice to melt with adjectives. The ice melted but level was failed. I tried spawning salt and using that on the ice. The ice melted but level was failed. Eventually I resorted to Google. It seems "with science" in the Scribblenauts world means "don't try to solve this yourself, spawn a scientist to do it for you". Good god, such a stupid anti-scientific attitude to science.Finally there is Lilly, poor, poor Lilly. First off she is a Ms. Male by which I mean she is a female version of Maxwell with no other distinguishing personality or features except for being pink. Then she gets damseled in the opening cut-scene. Then you find that each level you can unlock one more of her siblings as a new playable character if you don't want to play as Maxwell, how many of these are sisters? None. Seemingly the other god knows how many playable characters are brothers. *sigh* Maybe Lilly becomes playable after the end of the story missions and she is released from her predicament but if so it is too little and far too late.No. Enough. There is joy in the heart of this game but after you're over the initial rush of apparent power the limitations and all the rubbish that come with it suck all the joy of it. I dare say some might say that as a grown man I shouldn't be surprised that I can't enjoy this since I'm hardly the target audience but honestly given the amount of twisted crap that is wrapped up with this game there is no way I'd let a child play it.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												The idea of this game has a lot of potential. Making something appear by typing its name is really fun, but in this game it is horribly limited. Part of the problem is you can't summon pop culture icons, and that would be very important since they are so infused in the modern world. There are many other things you can't summon, too many for this game to be titled "unlimited". Experimenting with the game will quickly become boring in a few hours, if that. The story mode is simple and charming at first, but there is no challenge introduced as you progress, making it quickly become boring. In short, its a fun, cute game to play for an hour or two, but it will rapidly become boring after that, and its not worth more than a few dollars top.

												In the third scribblenauts game the old gameplay having to cross various terrains to reach the starrite is unfortunely lost in favor of new gameplay where you help people by giving them items they ask for. most of these items are fairly obvious meaning less encouragement to come up with a creative solution. Additionally some of the answers are references to pop culture such as LOTR, which if you dont know about your not going to be able to solve. After finishing the game you find out about this list of 200 items you have to summon off a list thats annoying to access requiring multliple clicks threw menus to reach.The game also lacked much of a plot, your sister is frozen and you have to unfreeze her thats pretty much it. I would reccomend getting a different scribblenauts game over this one. The first 2 are much more interesting but they arent on steam, that leaves unmasked. I played very little unmasked but it seemed pretty similair but had a lot more interesting features.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Scribblenauts Unlimited is a fun, interesting, and innovative game for about 15 minutes. The game concept is engrossing enough; type any word or phrase and it will appear in-game. Y'all already know I was rolling with my posse of George Washington and Napoleon on the reg, sporting a tuxedo and wielding a flamethrower atop my giant flying jaguar. The open nature also makes the options to resolve "quests" interesting (we'll get to that later). I was a vengeful God, and if a person needed, say a bag of money, I would make them blind in return. If they wanted a child, it would be a gargantuan, dying, amphibious baby. And for a while the gimmick was entertaining. However, the gimmick gets old fast. Because that's all the game is; an interesting game concept and gimmick that is stretched into a full-length video game.The game quests are extremely shallow and repetitive. An NPC says "I need something that can do this/is like this/is this, and you oblige them. This process takes an average of 7 seconds to complete, and is the core of game progression. Like I said, this provides plenty of opportunity for humorous moments. But the game counts on you to make those moments happen. And there's really no incentive to do so; because the game is so repetitive, you want to just blow through it and be done with the quests. As the game progresses I became more and more utilitarian with my answers. I just didn't have the heart to try and make humor out of what felt like work. "I need a friend" - give them a dog. "I want to write" - give them a pencil. THe process became so monotonous and boring it was unbearable.This is a game that brings the player an interesting but temporarily engaging concept and absolutely drab quests and asks the player to bring the fun. Whereas "make your own fun games" like Just Cause and GTA create diversity in how you can create that fun, Scribblenauts is dull and taxing throughout. Just knowing that this game exists is about as much fun as playing it. Don't buy it, not even on sale.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												I played a couple of Scribblenauts games on DS and absolutely loved them.  It may have been the novelty of it that really got me hooked, or maybe the fact that I had to learn the "tricks" of the game as I went along.  This game was terribly disappointing by comparison.Most of the "puzzles" or "quests" are insanely simple.  I was stumped maybe 3 times at most.  Otherwise it was a bunch of, "I'm hungry, make me something to eat," or, "My cat's stuck in the tree, please get him down," or, "I'm bored, find something to entertain me."  Sandwich, ladder, clown, EASY!!!  Given the name "Scribblenauts Unlimited" and the fact the game is Steam Workshop enabled, I was under the impression other people would be making levels and challenges.  Wow!  Was I ever wrong!  The fact that you can create your own objects is a poor consolation, especially considering most of the changes are simply visual and the item editor comes with NO GUIDANCE WHATSOEVER!  I tried to make an object starting with a cannonball as the template and it was never any more useful than an actual cannonball.I don't recall how many areas/quest there are, but there are way too many given the overall difficulty of the game.  The developers definitely went for quantity over quality and I think that's where the game really suffers.  Too many challenges that aren't challenging and too many objects that aren't all that unique.  Even at a dirt cheap price this game feels more like a chore than an actual game.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												Pretty great for kids that don't require much of a challenge, but for an adult it's a 'make-your-own-fun' kind of game. You play a young boy venturing out into the world with a notebook that makes him an itty-bitty god, letting you create anything your imagination can conjure up, as long as it's not copywritten or mildly controversial (you can create God, but no Hitler). Challenges are usually a slight riddle or a character telling  you what they want, leaving you to generate it with your notebook. Unfortunately, most of these challenges are without real challenge, leaving it up to the player to try and eake out some of the more creative solutions the studio programmed in. Still, the game is attractive, has a pleasant cheeky sense of humor, and has some really nice music, but as a game it usually as demanding as that children's game where you put the round peg in the round hole. Charming, but more ingenuity need to be applied to how to engage the player's imagination.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2013
												Compared to the previous titles, this installment of Scribblenauts is crippling and crushes the creative spirit.There are no actual puzzles; you never have to create elaborate setups, get creative with your summon variety, or make use of stacking/nesting/connecting. You don't even have to move, really. There are no challenges. There are only fill-in-the-blank scenarios.That's it.Even Kirby games have challenge and variety.For a game whose central theme is goodwill and charity, I'm wondering why I'm asked to arm and harm others, and break criminals out of prison. With a name like Bruiser, I'm pretty sure his incarceration was not unjust.My initial excitement by a VA appearance from Jennifer Hale was immediately snuffed when I realized she would spend the entire game in the barn while her 41 brothers explored the world and had incredible adventures. By the time I freed her from the barn, I was sick of the game and couldn't continue.As a Scribblenauts fan, this game was incredibly disappointing. The free iPhone version is leagues better, and it doesn't even have adjective mechanics.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Actual game play felt like it was suited more for little kids. This just did not fit my style of games and did not hold much enjoyment for me. I would not negatively review this game based on its playing aspect. I am sure it can be quite enjoyable to many people and kids.I do give it a negative review though on its technical problem starting up. I run eyefinity (multi-monitor, wide resolution). Most games that are not compatible with eyefinity will either drop resolution and clone image across screens and allow you to start up and change resolution via options to your liking. This one however starts up functioning in eyefinity but it is zoomed in at a horrible distance. At the main menu it is so zoomed in you can not access the start/options/exit, etc. You are forced to tab out and terminate the game. Only work around I could do was disable eyefinity from desktop before running the game.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												I've only played this one and the original Scribblenauts, so it's possible that this is what all the current games are like, but ...The basic idea of Scribblenauts is that you are let loose in a series of levels, each of which contains a "Starite." As Max, your goal is to obtain the Starite by any means necessary. Fortunately, you are armed with a magic notebook; when Max writes nouns the game understands in the notebook, whatever he's written is summoned into reality. With Scribblenauts Unlimited he gains the ability to use adjectives, as well, even adding them to existing objects.In the first Scribblenauts game, getting the Starite usually (but not always) required solving a physics puzzle. In Scribblenauts Unlimited, though, you generally just end up walking up to an NPC, being told the NPC wants something, and then writing down examples of whatever is requested.For instance, an NPC might be described as a "Hungry Vegetarian." Write down "apple" "pancake" "carrot" get Starite. (That was off the top of my head, but it might actually be in the game. That's the level of sophistication.) It's less a video game and more a vocabulary test. Oh, and since a LOT of puzzles require knowledge of English-language culture, don't even expect to be able to use it to help learn the language.It doesn't help that in the first game Max would often find himself in danger and need to find a way to protect himself. Here, the first thing you do in each level is click on Max and add adjectives like "Immortal Flying Fireproof" to yourself and then roam with impunity.Basically ... if the first Scribblenauts was easy, Scribblenauts Ultimate barely qualifies as an activity book. An expensive, overproduced activity book.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Buy this. Buy it. Buy it now. If it's on sale, buy two copies. This is great.The art style is simple yet pretty to look at. You can use a magical note book to spawn items in order to innovatively solve problems in new and exciting ways. Problem: Car being parked illegally. Solution: Spawn a rideable block of cheese with wings. Tie rope from the cheese to the car and tow it away! With the workshop support, the only end to the game is your imagination. You can literally have anything you can think of. Good points - Great art style.- Hours of gameplay.- Amusing situations.- Workshop support.- Child friendly.- Main character has the same name as me. Bad points- Character creation is very very fiddly and can be annoying. - Running out of ideas due to lack of imagination.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Frankly, it was an honest effort. I'll give them that. But Scribblenauts just didn't catch my attention. Sure, I got 3 hours into it, but I have at least 10 times that in CS:GO, let alone the 60 TIMES record I have in Garry's Mod.      It's enjoyable for the begginning, and I'm sure younger audiences might play this game for months upon months, but when you suddenly turn 13 and realize there's games like Call of Duty out there for you to play, the replay value drops rediculously. Better than nothing, but I'm just not left satisfied. 4/10 stars.Auther's Note(s)     With all due respect to the hours upon hours it must of taken to make Scribblenauts, it just isn't worth the money I put into it. And I even got it on sale. It's fine if you're younger though, so if you've got a 5/6 year-old brother or sister that wants something to do, it's considerable to buy it for them.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2013
												A cute looking problem solving sand box game that involves spawning, labeling, destroying and manipulating objects and entities with an educational angle for kids. The premise is simple with multiple objectives in each map, but the possibilities and combinations are limitless and often hilarious, with many shards and starite objects to collect once all objectives have been met.For achievement hunters, the full starite collection will require trying a huge selection of outfits, weapons, items and situations, but the process is relatively fun if, albeit, slow. Good fun for kids. 3.5/5

content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												After finishing this game I can certainly say that is is worth playing. It has replay ability but its mostly about the first play through. If you are playing I'd say keep an eye on the shards in the menu, otherwise you'll end up at the end grinding for ages to get the shard pieces. Its fun to write some random stuff to solve odd puzzles that in most cases can be solved simply but why solve it simply when you can summon kathulu or a giant pink fish or a tiny tank. Games like this bring out the weird and sometimes darker parts of my personality. There are some problems where I had to look up on Wiki to find out how to complete a task but for the majority you can find some way to 100% the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												This game is perfect for all ages, (Mostly 6-10+ of course,) and It contains very fun and addictive gameplay.This is a large game, therefor it will take some fair amount of time to finish, but the time is worth it. The game itself is based on creating anything you want, even making things for the game on the Steam Workshop.It is a curiously adventurous game, in some perspectives. There are multiple selections of the game you can explore, and play in. You can costumize your own character, male or female, and you have completely no limits to your imagination, and what you can create.What I created? A Giant Flying Rocket Sheep.What else I created? A Tiny Red Hulk.You have completely no limits to what you can create, and therefor it makes it the perfect SandBox game for any Indie or Adventurous gamers out there. The cartoony graphics might not be the best, but the gameplay itself makes up for more than enough of this.I say this is worth a buy, and a very, very, enjoyable and creative-building game.Good Job, Scribblenauts.

												Type something in and watch it appear on your screen or if it doesn't exist, create it yourself! Scribblenauts offers vast complexity underneath its primitive visuals--much more than I expected. 												Excellent. This game is a fun word puzzler that tests your imagination. The only faults I find are that a few of the puzzles are a bit on the ambiguous side (meaning some trial and error or online research), and most of the puzzles needed for the achievements are even more ambiguous while being completely superfluous to the actual game (meaning you are expected to do those more exact and unclear combinations in the sandbox mode). The story is charming and the mechanics work well. I'm definitely looking forward to the sequel(s) on the way.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												I bought this for $60 when it came out.[screams internally]If you liked Scribblenauts on the DS, then you will like this game. It does have a lot of content in the way of puzzles, but they are not particularly stressful or challenging; don't expect a Dark Souls experience is all I'm saying. You really can create anything... as long as that something is not a proper noun or copyrighted material. But then there is the Steam Workshop and the Object Editor, which allows your imagination to go wild.If I bought this game for $10-20, then that is a good deal for what is essentially an object creation sandbox. There might be some limitations in the way the objects interact, but all in all it is a good game toy. But $60 was highway robbery. Fun while it lasted.I give it 7 out of 10 transparent zombie purple immortal starites.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												There were games that I looked forward to playing but then it turn out to be a dissapointment. This one is actually the other way around, I thought this might be something that I don't like, but it might be a good educational game to play with kids.  But after half an hour into the game, I was really surprised that not only I like this game, I love it.This game is not only fun, but funny as well.  In a nutshell, you help people by creating 'objects' or add an adjective to something, then you get a star.  So you go around and help people, and you clear stages/area around the world.  Like I mentioned, it's actually good to play around kids.  When you think about it, the whole theme of the game is about helping people, so not only it seems educational, it is also a nice game to play with kids.What I really like about the game is the freedom to express your imagination, and there is always more than one way to do things here.  Before I played this game, I have this preconception that this is one of those game that is very linear, you have to use the right word for anything; but, that's totally not the case here, the flexibility of this game truly amazed me.  Also, I like the vast amount of objects you can create, combined with different adjectives.  It almost seems like there is infinite possiblities of objects you can create in this game(hence the name, "Unlimited"?).I also love the humour in this game, lots of pop culture reference, it's like lots of spoofs from movies and such.  And it gets better if you are the type of person like me who like to create objects that make the situation even funnier.  This game is generally easy, but sometimes it can make you think really hard.  So if you don't know what objects or adjectives to add, you can always move on to do another one.  That brings me to another thing I like about this, you can play this game at your own pace.  You don't have to spend certain amount of time in one sitting.  You can even spend like 1 minute in this game, maybe help one guy, save the game, and come back later to play more.There really isn't any story to this game, I technically finished the game under 10 hours and saw the 'ending'  by collecting 60 stars, but there seem to be a total of 106 stars.  I will probably play till I get all of the stars.  This is my first Scribblenauts game, I will definately play more of other Scribblenauts games.

												This sequel to Scribblenauts is truly a technically impressive feat, but it is very offensive to someone who is a radical Muslim such as myself. In this game, you play a boy who can create anything by writing it in his magic book, including a huge variety of living creatures - which become even more diverse with the new adjective system. The Koran says that only Allah can create life. Often times the game encourages cannabilistic activities, and this is against the word of Allah as described in the Koran, unless of course the subject in question is an enemy fighter or an adulterer. However in the case of Scribblenauts, you are prompted to feed a cannibal at a restaraunt, and the only way I could continue is by feeding him a fried baby. Truly a disgraceful game to our great creator. 2/10 would jihad again.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2012
												Scribblenauts is a game about writing words. The words you write will be created. You can use this to solve puzzles if you're lame. If you're not you will create a pile of hats, wear them all, laugh gleefully, then force a ninja hamster to fight against a samurai cactus. There will be people caught in the crossfire. Lots of people. After this, you will call forth the 4 horsemen of the apocalypse to clean up any survivors. Having experienced the greatest thing ever you will then probably die yourself.After that you can do puzzles I guess.Why are you even reading this anyway? You either love Scribblenauts or you think its a poorly executed gimmick. If you like Scribblenauts this is for you. I obviously love Scribblenauts.But even if you don't like Scribblenauts it has all the hats. All of them.And with the new Object Creator, if there's a hat that doesn't exist you can MAKE YOUR OWN HAT. Then you can upload it to the Steam Workshop so everyone can experience the glory that is YOUR HAT.10/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Okay, it's silly, but what did you expect? This game is much more addictive than I thought it would be, and I was very surprised to see how much time I've spent playing it (and usually procrastinating doing very important things at the same time). The challenges are usually very easy to complete, which may put some people off of the game, but there are also many creative ways to solve puzzles - finding new ways of solving the same puzzle can be a lot of fun! Overall, it's a fun game that is useful for burning time (so I strongly reccomend it to those who have just finished exams and have a very long holiday ahead of them!).

content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
												After finishing this game I can certainly say that is is worth playing. It has replay ability but its mostly about the first play through. If you are playing I'd say keep an eye on the shards in the menu, otherwise you'll end up at the end grinding for ages to get the shard pieces. Its fun to write some random stuff to solve odd puzzles that in most cases can be solved simply but why solve it simply when you can summon kathulu or a giant pink fish or a tiny tank. Games like this bring out the weird and sometimes darker parts of my personality. There are some problems where I had to look up on Wiki to find out how to complete a task but for the majority you can find some way to 100% the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												This game is perfect for all ages, (Mostly 6-10+ of course,) and It contains very fun and addictive gameplay.This is a large game, therefor it will take some fair amount of time to finish, but the time is worth it. The game itself is based on creating anything you want, even making things for the game on the Steam Workshop.It is a curiously adventurous game, in some perspectives. There are multiple selections of the game you can explore, and play in. You can costumize your own character, male or female, and you have completely no limits to your imagination, and what you can create.What I created? A Giant Flying Rocket Sheep.What else I created? A Tiny Red Hulk.You have completely no limits to what you can create, and therefor it makes it the perfect SandBox game for any Indie or Adventurous gamers out there. The cartoony graphics might not be the best, but the gameplay itself makes up for more than enough of this.I say this is worth a buy, and a very, very, enjoyable and creative-building game.Good Job, Scribblenauts.
