content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												I definitely recommend this game to people of all ages! Scribblenauts Unlimited is simple enough for younger folk, but at the same time, it's great for adults as well. There are so many ways to get creative and just have fun with your surroundings. Basically, you play as Maxwell and your goal is to help your fellow man with a magical notebook in order to save your sister. The different worlds and the people/creatures who inhabit them are so fun to interact with. I'm not sure about what's available in the Steam Workshop, as I have yet to try out any of the custom content. I love this game, but I do have only one complaint: the game can get repetitive at times if you decide to use the same solution for multiple puzzles.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 12, 2013
												Scribblenauts is a fun puzzle game with inventive solutions to problems others are having. You (Maxwell) must save your sister by collecting starite which you collect by helping people. You can help others by using your magical notebook that alows you to create anything* that you can think of. Many of the solutions to these puzzles require some knowledge of many different topics and is a really fun way to test your memory bank and problem solving skills. I recommend this game if you want to be given a problem and must figure out the solution only using nouns and adjectives to modify those nouns. The pencil is mightier than the sword, especially if that pencil, paired with Maxwell's magical notebook, can create Excalibur.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												TL;DR: Definitely worth a play if on sale (I paid $4.99) and you are new to the series, but overall not a good enough game to warrant a recommendation.If you've never played a game like Scribblenauts before, this is definitely worth a play. The play mechanics were unique to anything I've ever played before, so it was definitely worth the sale price. If you *have* played a game like this before though, I'm not sure if I would recommend this one.As much as I enjoyed the premise at the beginning, as I progressed, I found the game got stale. I was hoping for a much stronger puzzle-solving element to the game, but unfortunately everything is pretty straight forward, and there are a lot of clues that are force-fed to you. By the end of the game I was still somewhat entertained, but mostly I was just doing my duty in trying to complete it.

												At first, I bought this game because I was staying for a week at a place where this 5 year old followed me around and stared at my computer screen. Of course I couldn't play my usual Team Fortress 2 or Skyrim because "Oh you shouldn't scare the little kids" I turned it on and the beginning was... meh. As I countinued on, I found myself playing it more and more. There were great references, entertaining missions, and lots of things to do. The point of this game is to help people around the land with strange/silly problems. The soulutions can be something boring like "Hamburger" or... "Hipster Cthulu". This may sound like a slightly childish and bothering game, but even I was entertained. If your looking for a nice calming game just to take a break from all the crowbarings and zombie-killings, buy this game9/10 Needs More Missions

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												This game is great. It's just like any other Scribblenauts game. You know, do good things for people using the objects you bring into the world and you get a Starite. Only in this one, you can create your own objects and characters. Not just bringing them into the world, but actually creating them. You can decide what they do under certain circumstances, and what they have the abilities to do in those situations. The system for creating the objects is easy to master, but at first it does take a while to understand. You can also create the different characters that you can play as. This game is spectacular, and I highly suggest that you buy it as soon as possible.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												This should definitely be categorized as a children's game, but it is still very charming and fun to play.  The real fun for me is in seeing how creative I can get with my answers, and I've been surprised a couple times as to what works.  It shows a lot of care on the developer's part.  You can always get past a puzzle with an obvious or easy answer, and often times just a handful of words can get you past many puzzles, but I urge anyone that's playing to dig into their vocabulary to try to be as creative as possible.  This is my first Scribblenauts game so it is a very fresh experience for me, however unless the formula is changed up quite a bit on other releases, I can't see myself purchasing another game in the series.  As it stands though, I would still recommend any and everyone at least try one game from the series.

My girlfriend told me that I should become a PR director for this game once I told her how great it is because she didn't see how great it was but I think she is more bias than I am. Ever thought of riding a flying shark through all the levels?  You can do that too like Napolean fighting the Chinese in world war 3.  I have submitted a marriage proposal to this game without my girlfriend knowing yet.  I hope she is okay with paligamy since us three should get together really well.  Also the solution to all problems is either putting the adjective "Gone" or "Naked".  "I am lonely!" well now you're naked, therefore not lonely.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2013
												Even if it have a childish facade there is a lot of chaotic fun to be had here for kids and adults alike. The game consists mainly of simple puzzles scattered around the various different levels in the game, where you can write a word to spawn nearly anything to help you solve it. Kids can get a educational experience with learning simple logic things in an engaging way, while adults can have fun times in trying to bend the rules of what the game allows you to do.Cook food for a school cafeteria? Use normal cafeteria food, or just use human flesh! Then once the puzzle is solved you can make everybody catch fire and die from exploding banana pudding if you so wish, because why not!You can also create your own objects which is pretty cool, even if the editor have some limitations. The editor and workshop integritation makes it so if a object is missing from the wordlist in the game you can create it yourself or find out if somebody else made it, which has lots of fun potential too.It's perhaps a game that requires a bit of effort on your own part to make it truly special, but if you are a creative person or have a young child with a lot of imagination this is a pretty solid game for all ages

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												Based on a popular Nintendo DS game, Scribblenauts is an action puzzler where the player assumes the rooster-headed roll of Max, the protangonist. Lily, Max's sister, must be saved from a curse caused by abuse of a magic notebook. The notebook is the core mechanic of the game - the ability to describe an object and have that object appear in the world to be used by Max or the game itself. It's a simple premise, but one where the huge open ended variety of the dictonary used by the game really makes the puzzles (which get progressively vague or specific, including required actions with items) stand out as both endearing and enjoyable.The game itself has a decent length, with a solid ending that wraps up the PG storyline in a neat package worthy of Aesop. The quality graphics, catchy and unobtrusive sound track, and genuinely creative player-centered gameplay should delight pretty much anyone of any age and ability. Probably the only gripes I have are the removal of particles (no "bag of salt", you have to make a bag and salt separately then put the salt in the bag) and that it's very easy to destroy required parts of the level, necessitating lengthy replaying of certain challenges.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 18, 2013
												Imagine you're playing Pokémon, but none of the enemy trainers' Pokémon ever increase in power, and your Pokémon can't take damage. You spend the whole game squashing Pidgeys and Caterpies. Sure, you can still try and customize your team or fill out your Pokédex or whatever--that's all still there, but the game never rewards you for it, because there's no encounter where it makes a difference. That's Scribblenauts."We need a captive to put in the prison!" Notebook: CAPTIVE. "We need an experienced sailor to man the helm!" Notebook: EXPERIENCED SAILOR. "We need someone who can cook!" Notebook: COOK. "I need something to extinguish this fire!" Go go gadget FIRE EXTINGUISHER. You can try to be creative, but the game doesn't reward you for it in any way. In and of itself, there is no challenge here. It's less of a game than a toy. Of course, there are certainly worse toys you could play with. You can have a good time screwing around in the sandbox for a while before it gets old, and it's a great game to give to your kids. If you like Mad Libs, you'll probably get a kick out of changing firemen into flying rainbow-colored zombie firemen in stylish hats and whatnot.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												The endless possibilities are intoxicating at first, but once that wears off you'll see just how, well, boring the tasks you're supposed to complete really are.  After six hours I was using my imagination to come up with the fastest solutions possible to just get things over with.  A lot of the time near the end of the game i didn't even bother creating objects if I could avoid it and just edited adjectives to accomplish everything.There are a few rare instances where the game makes things more challenging by imposing restrictions on you, like a gauntlet you have to run without being able to use adjectives synonymous with invincible.  Unfortunately these aren't very common.Still, it was fun for a few hours and could be worth it if it's on sale.  There's also all the stuff made by the steamworks community that I've yet to check out.

												I definitely recommend this game to people of all ages! Scribblenauts Unlimited is simple enough for younger folk, but at the same time, it's great for adults as well. There are so many ways to get creative and just have fun with your surroundings. Basically, you play as Maxwell and your goal is to help your fellow man with a magical notebook in order to save your sister. The different worlds and the people/creatures who inhabit them are so fun to interact with. I'm not sure about what's available in the Steam Workshop, as I have yet to try out any of the custom content. I love this game, but I do have only one complaint: the game can get repetitive at times if you decide to use the same solution for multiple puzzles.

												If you're a fan of the DS titles, then you'll have a blast with this one. My only complaint is that after you beat it, it gets really boring, but for the $20.00 game that it is, it's a great addition to the series. With the new Object editor, you can make solving puzzles more hilarious than the previous installments. Unfortunately, it doesn't have much replay value, either, so if you do plan on buying it, either wait for it to go on sale, or pressure your friends to get it for you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												This game is many things, but above all, it is delightful. The graphics aren't glorious and it doesn't have a rich story accompanied by hours of cutscenes, but it is absolutely delightful. Let me give you an idea of what I'm talking about. This game is like one of those things that I dreamed about playing when I was little. "Wouldn't it be cool if someone made a game where you could make any object appear?". I'd like to imagine the look on my 6-year-old face if I saw that, yes, someone actually made that. Granted, you can't spawn absolutely everything, but that would actually be impossible, considering that you would also need to make art for pedophiles, glockenspiels, all the members of Monty Python, rare engrams, and New York City, along with everything in the known universe. But hey! You can add adjectives!To make things even better, this is the definitive edition of the game, in my opinion. Not only can you make your own objects by using other in-game things you can spawn and then adding scripts to them, but you can also share your creations to Steam Workshop. This is an absolute joy. Sure, you can't spawn Dragonball Z characters by default, but you can through the wonders of the Steam Community! This adds a whole new level to the game. It was enough that they let you create your own things to spawn, but the fact that they also allowed you to share and download your and other people's creations adds to the experience. I could spend hours just screwing around with this game. But of course, there is a mission mode. The missions are fun, because they force you to utilize your skill to spawn an uncountable amount of things to solve problems. This adds an element of logic to the game. Also, the music and graphics are charming, although simple.Even though sandbox games have recently become third-person open-world games exclusively, it's still fun to partake in experiences like Scribblenauts Unlimited. Sit back and let your creativity flow.

Posted: June 22, 2014
												A very nice game that's sort of like a sandbox but not fully, you can create almost anything and the workshop offers a variety of other content you could use, the ending is heartwarming and I would definitely recommend this game for the younger community. You can also make your own objects using the object editor and then publish those to the workshop for others to enjoy, although, for me at least, it is kind of diffictult to make something you can really be proud of because you don't get that big a variety to work with, but that's no reason not to pick up this game.If you enjoy games that are like a sandbox but theres a storyline to complete, this is the game for you, I would recommend this a thousand times over if you are young, it's even quite fun for the older community sometimes!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												If you've seen the commericals for this then you know what to expect, a fairly simple and fun puzzle game. I've nearly beaten the game after several months (playing only a small ammount each week) and I still consider it fun after about ten hours of non-continuous gameplay. For the $20.00 it costs to buy it at its regular price I feel like I have gotten my moneys worth out of it though I might suggest waiting for a sale if you are not sure if you want it or not. In terms of gameplays though I can see people getting annoyed at the fairly repetitive nature of the game play which ammounts to see some people with a problem, firguring out what they need to solve the problem, typing it in the book then giving them that item. And while I aggree that it does get annoying if you are planning on trying to beat it in a single sitting I think the game is ment to be played in short bursts, which is the way that I have been playing it and have found it quite fun. The only other problem I have found is that sometimes it doesn't know simple items like winter coat, instead you have to kind of simplify the idea down to its more basic components (such as wool jacket for winter coat). Overall I would recomend this game for children or people who just like a simple, fun puzzle game. P.S you can summon cthulhu and have him battle robot pigs, so there's that.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												I find this game very enjoyable to play and I think many others do too. The story is a little childish but, seriously, come on. Who plays Scribblenauts for the story? You get a magical notepad at the very start of the game which you can use to create any object. The puzzles are quite enjoyable and humorous if you can finish it in an unlikely manner (like putting out a huge fire with a microscopic raindrop). You can also make weapons and mounts and clothes. You dress up as a samurai with a blue mouldy bazooka riding a flying robotic squid through the sky. Or a knight with a rusty cheese knife riding an orange shoe.The possibilities in this game are endless and I'm sure that you'll enjoy blowing things up with explosive goats and laughing at the humorous results just as much as I do (If you meet the imagination requirements).
